talk.start.para: —by leave-I table a petitioning letter signed by 45 citizens of Tasmania calling for the Franklin River to be declared an inviolable national park. I ask leave of the Senate to have the text of the letter incorporated in Hansard.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
14 October, 1982.
Senator Brian Archer,
The Senate,
Parliament House,
Canberra. A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Archer,
PRIVATE MEMBERS BILL. SOUTH-WEST TASMANIA.
As Tasmanians we are appealing to you to support the proposed private members bill, declaring the Franklin River ''an inviolable national park''.

When Mr Gray became leader of the State Parliamentary Liberal Party, he announced the No 1 policy was an ''immediate start to negotiations with the Federal Government to have Bass Strait declared a strike free national sea road, backed by State and Federal legislation''. This was deemed essential to promote business confidence to invest in Tasmania.

After gaining Government this policy has been shelved in favour of the emotional appeal of the ''DAM IS ESSENTIAL FOR SURVIVAL''. (Examiner Oct 11). The dam is to be a panacea which will automatically ensure business investment for the State.
While the World economy is expected to improve, will boom conditions in mining and metal industries return to Australia? These industries were the principal users of the State's electricity.

Experts have pointed out that a South-West power scheme has a longer lead time than a thermal power station. The Turnbull Report (Sept 81) is even more relevant today. ''The State could be faced with the bleak prospect of attempting to sell off an excess of expensive, non competitive power''.
We have a Premier who has tried to correct the former Labour Government's economic mismanagement, but he has shown his inexperience in his handling of the South-West issue.

We are a State of only 427,300 people, reliant on the goodwill of mainland people. Is it rational that Mr Gray should antagonise the media and people of the mainland in order to safeguard jobs for hydro construction workers?

It is time the Federal Government took action concerning Mr Gray's barrage of public statements-the warnings to Mr Fraser to kept out of the South-West, and threats of secession from the Commonwealth. For how long should a Federal Government be subservient to a Premier representing only 3% of Australia's population?

If we accept World Heritage Listing, The South-West would become only the thirtieth natural area so listed. Surely this would benefit all Australia, and particularly Tasmania. Overseas people would become aware of Tasmania as a place of scenic beauty, worthy of inclusion in an overseas tour.
At stake is a power station with a small generating capacity (180 m.w.) which would cause desecration of an area of ''irreplaceable'' beauty and flood the Franklin valley caves.
Naturalists and Scientists throughout the world have proclaimed that if Australia allows this destruction to occur, it will be guilty of an act of gross vandalism.

We sincerely trust that the proposed Bill will not be shelved or evaded on any technical ground-but will gain the support of patriotic Government members, who place the future inheritance of Australians, above placating an inexperienced Premier who mistakes belligerency for strength.

The Young Liberal Movement expresses the concern of all thinking members of the younger generation. The Gray Government shows no respect for the Senate, and is proceeding with the power scheme regardless of what the Senate Select Committee may report.
These circumstances call for strong action by Federal Parliament now.

petition.title: Plant Variety Rights
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seed should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any systems giving 'property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects, namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

question.block.title: URANIUM MINING: AUSTRALIAN LABOR PARTY POLICY

talk.start.para: —Has the Minister for National Development and Energy seen Press reports of astonishing statements by the South Australian Opposition Leader, Mr Bannon, that the mining of uranium at Roxby Downs would go ahead under a South Australian Labor government? Is such a statement consistent with the announced Federal Labor Party's policy on uranium mining? Is Mr Bannon's statement not blatant political opportunism? More importantly, does such opportunism not reflect the uncertainty of Australian Labor Party policies in an area of great economic importance where there is an essential need for industry to be able to depend on government policies in order that it might confidently commit the investment of the vast sums of capital that such projects require?

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. The question asked for an interpretation of Australian Labor Party policy. With all respect to the Minister, I do not think he is in a position to be able to interpret policy, nor is he responsible for that policy.

—Order! There is no point of order. This point has been raised many times in the chamber, and this has been allowed. I remind all honourable senators that in the past two weeks many questions have been asked which have more than appeared to relate to a certain situation in a certain State.

—I take a point of order. Mr President, I do not want to canvass the ruling that you have just made, but I ask for a refinement of it from you. I do not want to take on either side on this question, but, as I understand it, the Minister has been asked specifically and clearly to give his impressions of a policy announcement of the Australian Labor Party at the weekend. With the greatest respect to you, I suggest that it is outside Standing Orders and outside not only the letter but also the whole spirit of Question Time.
—I take note of what Senator Chipp has said, but the practice has been accepted in this place in the past. The responsibility rests with--
—That does not make it right.

—Well, it is a matter that can be referred to the Standing Orders Committee. I am working within the practice, as I understand it. I call the Leader and ask him to take into consideration the points that have been raised when he responds to the question.

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —I was asked whether I had seen the reported statements of Mr Bannon. Assuming that they are reported correctly, the answer is that I have seen them and that they appear to be diametrically opposed to reports from that quarter over the years. That is the first point. Secondly, as I clearly understood the statements made in the past, any future moves for contractual arrangements on uranium would be subject to decisions by a Labor government and therefore could be fraught with uncertainty.
—It will not be long now.

—The only uncertainty that arises at the moment is, of course, the nervousness of the Labor Party in South Australia which is willing to indulge in opportunism because it fears the inevitability of its defeat. The fact is that no enterprise could willingly enter into the massive outlays of hundreds, even thousands, of millions of dollars for the development of an enterprise like Roxby Downs without the assurance that it and any ancillary developments would proceed without qualification and that within the developments contracts could be made that would survive over the years. No such assurance can possibly be given or accepted within South Australia from the Labor side of politics and therefore, of course, the promise is without any foundation of credibility.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the consumer price index bulletin issued yesterday attribute more than half of the eight-year record September quarter CPI increase to higher government charges and higher prices induced by government taxes? Why then does the Government insist that excessive wage increases are responsible for the eight-year record increase? To the extent that wage increases have increased prices, does he believe that taking up the so-called resources boom-for example, his enthusiastic support for Rundle-touched off the big wage demands?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —I have not had the opportunity to study in detail the breakdown of the consumer price index, but as I have read it--
—You have been too busy reading Labor Party policy.

—Yes, and why not? The people of Australia deserve to have the facts told to them about the imperfections in Australian Labor Party policy. Inherent in Senator Sibraa's question is the first element that a significant amount of the increase was in respect of charges-I think the figure was something in excess of one per cent or 1.3 per cent of the 3.5 per cent-and that those charges, particularly electric power charges, basically are heavily imposed by State governments.
—New federalism.

—Senator Button interjects that it is new federalism. Does new federalism have anything to do with the persistent ability of the States to generate power over the whole course of their history? Electricity charges, particularly in the largest State of New South Wales, have played a significant part.
—That is not true. That is just not true.

—Heavy increases in petrol tax charges and diesel charges, particularly in New South Wales, have also played a significant part. Let us hear Senator Walsh say 'That is not true' again, because we can get the figures for these increases. Of course, those charges have had a very heavy effect. I noted today that the editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald strongly oriented itself to the fact that one of the major cures to overcome future CPI increases would be to get a wage restraint understanding throughout Australia. Quite clearly, wage--
—You have not done very well, have you? You abandoned indexation.

—I am being helped enormously by the Labor Party. The Labor Party does not want me to draw attention to the fact that State governments, particularly State Labor governments, have a record increase in taxes and charges. This has had a very significant impact on the CPI. The CPI for the September quarter has some peculiar characteristics in that it is bringing into one quarter what would normally be spread over the September and December quarters. Nevertheless, if one reads the media today one will see that the commentators are insistent that one major way to get inflation down in the future is to establish wage restraint throughout Australia. Quite clearly, the flow-on of the very large upsurge of wages in the last financial year has moved into this quarter. There is still a hangover from that. I will obtain the detailed breakdown of the CPI. If there is further information to be given to the Senate I will be very happy to do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I preface my question by drawing his attention to an article which appeared in the Melbourne Age yesterday in which it is claimed that the Liberal Party has no health policy. Does the present Government's health policy provide for specific objectives? Does it also make provision for the manner in which these objectives are to be achieved? Is there any truth in the suggestion in the article that the Federal Government is seeking to reduce its policy and planning activities in the health care field?

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —Any health policy in Australian political terms would have several components. It would have a component related to the health of Australians. The Government certainly has a policy related to the health of Australians, health promotion and health promotion activities. The political realities in Australia today are that most health policy arguments relate not to health matters but to health financing matters. The Government does have a health policy relating to health financing. The policy is to ensure that all Australians have access to health care services which are of high quality and which are at a cost that the individual and the community can afford. Within that framework the Government is committed to maintain a mixture of private and public medicine, it is committed to the provision of private health insurance and it is committed to special assistance schemes for disadvantaged people and for those in genuine need.

answer.para: So, the criticism that has been made is quite unfounded and can be shown to be unfounded. In fact, many of the activities now being taken up by the States are in response to health policy thrusts by this Government which are designed to place responsibility where it belongs-with the States. The Government does not have a detailed health plan in the sense that the Opposition does. Unlike the Opposition, we do not believe that it is an appropriate approach to plan the detailed lives of individuals or to plan the lives of health professionals. We provide very heavily for health expenditure and have continued to do so over the years. In fact, I could answer Senator Hamer by saying that the record of the Government is one of very considerable involvement in defining its objectives, in making them known and in taking appropriate action to have the objectives put into effect.

question.speaker: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

talk.start.para: —I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate . I precede my question with a quotation attributed to Mr Anthony, the Deputy Prime Minister, on the front page of the Weekend Australian. Mr Anthony said that the disruptive and delaying tactics of the Senate are delaying the Government. He continued:

question.para: It has led to a log-jam of legislation which will have to be sorted out soon if the legislation needed by the Government to provide the welfare and tax benefits set out in the Budget is to be passed in time.

Is it not true that the log-jam, if there is one, is in fact in the House of Representatives and that whilst both parties on the Opposition side of the Senate agreed to expedite the Appropriation Bills on the basis that they would be introduced today-which was a change of mind by the Government-those Bills today are still being debated in the House of Representatives? Is it not true that, since the Government lost control of the Senate, of 230 Bills only three have been rejected, three have been referred to Senate committees and three have been discharged by the Government? In the light of this information, is it not a fact that this statement of Mr Anthony's is a blatant, palpable, wilful and provable lie?

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator, I ask you to withdraw the word 'lie'.
—A point of order, Mr President!

—Order! The Chair is on its feet. The word 'lie' has been regarded in this place as unparliamentary. Previous Presidents have ruled that that word may not be used in this chamber. I ask you for a withdrawal, Senator Chipp.
—Just use 'untruth'.
—Can I speak to the ruling or to a point of order?
—I will allow you to speak to a point of order.
—I submit to you that if I use the word 'untruth'--

—Order! Senator, I have overlooked one thing. I make it perfectly clear that I asked for a withdrawal of the word. Under those circumstances, I ask that you withdraw the word and, then, if you wish to speak on the matter, you may. I have given a ruling that the word must be withdrawn.
—You can do anything you like, but you cannot say something is a lie.
—Are you asking me to take action before I can even address you on it?

—With great respect to you, Senator Chipp-I did hear the comment of Senator Grimes-I want to make my position clear. I am following the practice in this place whereby the word 'lie' has always been regarded as unparliamentary . Previous Presidents have asked that the word be withdrawn. If it has related particularly to statements made by any honourable senator or any other member of parliament, that has been the practice in this place and I abide by that practice. I ask you to withdraw the word 'lie'.
—Mr President, can I raise a point of order at this stage?
—Order! I have ruled, Senator Mason.
—Mr President, you leave me with only two options-to move dissent from your ruling or to accept it. I very reluctantly do the latter because of my personal respect for you. I do so very reluctantly.

—Senator Chipp, if you wish to give expression to your concern about what might have been said in another place and if it is within Standing Orders to do so, I will accept it. I appreciate your response to my request to you to withdraw.

—Mr President, without canvassing your ruling, in the spirit of my question and without reference to the individual I have named, I suggest to you, with ultimate respect, that an untruth can be unintentional but a lie can never be unintentional and in this circumstance 'untruth' is a word that I substitute with great reluctance, out of respect for you, because I believe that in this instance the words that I have attributed to the person involved were intentional and were deliberate untruths.
—Have you finished your question?
—I shall quote him further. Mr Anthony went on to claim that the Democrats have no identifiable policies. These policies, totalling three booklets and 85 pages, are in his possession.
—Read them out.

—I suggest that in a matter as serious as this in which I am alleging that the Deputy Prime Minister is deliberately misleading the public the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in this place should go to his office and burst into hilarious laughter at his own jokes rather than interrupt my question .

—Order! I request that you ask your question. I ask that interjections cease while an honourable senator is on his or her feet asking a question. We have just dealt with a matter about which there has been some discussion and which is regarded as sensitive and very important by Senator Chipp. I ask that honourable senators show some respect for the question, the questioner engaged in asking the question at that moment and the response that comes from the Minister to whom the question is addressed. I again call Senator Chipp.

—Thank you, Mr President. Does not the statement that the Democrats have no identifiable policies identify itself as a deliberate falsification of the truth? In conclusion, does the Leader consider that a man such as Mr Anthony who has been spreading such palpably vicious and false statements is fit to be the Deputy Prime Minister of this country?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —Several weeks ago I had cause to write to each of the party leaders and to the Independent senator pointing out the great difficulties we will face in meeting the program ahead of us, giving them the program for the rest of the session, showing them that we have been using time very heavily on other than Government business and asking for their co-operation. In the last few days I have tabled in this chamber figures prepared by the officers of the Senate showing that the time devoted to Government business and Government legislation in this Budget session has been about half what it had been previously and what it had been when the present Government was in opposition. The fact of the matter is that on procedural matters that this Government has moved, with few exceptions, to speed up the handling of business one could generally rely upon the Australian Democrats to support the Australian Labor Party in opposing those procedural matters. That has to be understood.

answer.para: The answer is that, because of the volume of legislation and the slowness of its progress, it was necessary for me to write to the parties concerned pointing out the need to get particular legislation through by the end of this week and seeking further co-operation and a better allocation of time. For example, I am assured that there is no matter of public importance for discussion today, which is quite unlike the situation in the weeks beforehand.

talk.start.para: —Last week, too.

—I acknowledge that. I acknowledge that since I wrote this letter the Opposition parties have indicated that they will get this legislation through by the end of this week. The question asked of me was fundamental. It was: 'Has there been delay?'. The answer is yes, very considerable delay. Indeed, ever since the Democrats and the Opposition gained the ability to combine, as they do almost all the time, they have used that ability to delay business in the Senate, so that in the past it has been necessary for the Senate to sit for extra weeks to overtake those kinds of delays. The answer is that history and statistics are on the side of Mr Anthony. Mr Anthony in that regard--
—The House of Representatives got up early.

—I think that at the end of the May session the Senate sat several weeks longer than the House of Representatives. Let honourable senators opposite shout. I think in the earlier part of this Budget session about only 19 per cent of the time was devoted to Government legislation, as distinct from some 36 per cent or 38 per cent which was normal in the past. There has been delay. I am delighted that we are now deciding that there will not be delay. I was asked if I would reject Mr Anthony's statements that the Democrats have no identifiable policies. Let me say that it has been very clear, it was made clear by the Democrats before they started, that they could never indicate how they might vote in the Senate on any issue prior to the issue being debated; they would wait until the debate was over and then decide individually how they would vote. There cannot be identifiable policies if that is the case. But I think there is one quite clear identifiable policy. One can say almost all the time, if one wants to know how the Democrats will vote, they will vote as the limpet fish of the Labor Party. Let me make that perfectly clear. Over the history of the Senate and the history of the Democrats in the Senate, by and large the Democrat voting--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I would have thought that as my question was on the very delicate matter of the commodity of truth you might have exercised some control over the Minister, not only in his misuse of that commodity but also in the descriptions he has just applied to me and my colleagues by calling us limpet fish. That is quite offensive. If it is not unparliamentary, I would have thought you would have adjudged it to be offensive no matter to whom it was applied and that you would have asked for a withdrawal. As you did not, I do.
—Whilst I understand quite clearly that the Standing Orders do not rule out a description of a party-not an individual-in that situation--
—You use it all the time.
—Order!
—What an extraordinary situation.

—Order! I ask that honourable senators cease this continued interjecting. I have asked this on previous occasions in the chamber and I ask again today that honourable senators cease this continued interjecting. If individual senators continue to interject in an unparliamentary way I will take the necessary action. I again call the Leader of the Government.

—Because Senator Chipp said he finds those words offensive, I withdraw them. What I am saying is that on almost all matters of any significance in the Senate the Democrats can be relied upon to vote with the Labor Party and therefore, de facto, shall I say, they are sleeping partners of the Labor Party, if that is not an unparliamentary comment.
—A filthy allegation, a filthy sexist allegation.

—That happens to be an acceptable comment in company law. They may be sleeping partners towards the bottom of the harbour, who knows. As for the final part of the question, I regard Mr Anthony as an outstanding Australian and an outstanding leader, one I am proud to be associated with in coalition.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. At least one weekend newspaper in Western Australia carried an article about a large meat substitution racket in West Germany. Apparently kangaroo, donkey, horse and deer meat have been sold as beef and pork in that country for about two years. The article that I read implied that Australian exporters are involved in the racket. Will the Minister give me an assurance that the substitution was carried out in West Germany and does not involve Australian exporters or Australian meat inspectors?

answer.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —When I initially heard the reports I was relieved to hear animals described many of which are not native to Australia. That gave me some cause to hope that any difficulty would not be related to actions which had taken place within Australia. It appears that that is so. The difficulties being faced in West Germany in terms of meat substitution are not caused by actions which have been taken by Australian exporters. The Minister for Primary Industry issued a statement on 24 October. That helps to explain some of the points which might be in Senator Thomas's mind, and in the minds of senators who have been interjecting. Mr Nixon said in his Press statement that there had been no substitution in Australia of kangaroo meat for other products for the West German market and there was no fault in the Australian export inspection and certification procedure.

answer.para: Mr Nixon went on to point out that West Germany had in recent years become a significant importer of kangaroo meat from Australia as game meat for human consumption. That sort of meat is produced under stringent conditions in Australia. It is certified by the Export Inspection Service of the Department of Primary Industry as kangaroo game meat fit for human consumption. Kangaroo game meat exports to West Germany currently average 1,000 tonnes annually which is valued at about $2m. Australians and the Australian media should not be quick to make assumptions in this area which could be very damaging to Australian exports . I was pleased that the Minister for Primary Industry was so quickly able to make a public statement on this matter. It would appear that the difficulties currently being faced in Germany are not difficulties related to any problems in Australia.

talk.start.para: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation: Now that the Government has made a unilateral decision to construct a parallel runway into Botany Bay at Mascot airport in Sydney, can the Minister state the timetable involved for all stages of planning of construction leading up to an estimated commencement date and a completion date of the project? Will the Minister also state the estimated cost involved and plans that the Government might have for obtaining sand and fill for construction purposes?

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —The decision to proceed with the development of a new runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport has had to be made in view of the seriousness of congestion being experienced in Sydney. However, I assure the honourable senator that while the responsibility also revolves around the question of negotiation with the New South Wales Government in this regard, the decision rests with us; but the closest possible working relationship will be established with State government bodies in New South Wales. Already the Minister for Aviation and the Premier have exchanged letters, and the Secretary to the Department of Aviation will be meeting permanent heads of the New South Wales Government in the next few weeks on the whole question of joint government machinery in this regard.

answer.para: In coming to a decision to proceed with the development of a close-spaced parallel runway in Sydney, the Government is conscious of the lead time necessary before construction can commence. Before construction can start it will be necessary to carry out planning and feasibility analyses and other studies including those relating to sand fill, a point mentioned by Senator McClelland, location, an environmental analysis and the preparation of an environmental impact study. A review of the short-listed sites for a second major airport for Sydney will also need to be completed as soon as possible. That has been the subject of an announcement by the Government already. The Government has agreed that the selection of a site for that new airport will form part of the package of proposals necessary to meet the aviation needs of the whole Sydney region. It is expected that those processes will take about two years, after which time the project will be placed before the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. With the agreement of that Committee and the Parliament the construction of the second runway can commence and this is expected to be some time in 1985. Given full co-operation of all concerned with the project and fast track methods for planning and control of the project, I expect the runway to be operational before the end of this decade.

The cost of the runway project is dependent upon the source of sand fill, as identified by Senator Douglas McClelland. If sufficient sand is available within Botany Bay, the Commonwealth Department of Transport and Construction estimates the cost to be something of the order of $125m. However, if we have to go outside the bay for sand, the cost could rise to around $175m. The study to locate sand fill is to commence as soon as the necessary co-operation with the New South Wales Government is achieved and this is one of the matters that will be discussed at meetings next week.

question.block.title: CREDIT UNION AND BUILDING SOCIETY CHEQUES

talk.start.para: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that credit unions and building societies claim that there are inequities in the Bank Account Debits Tax Bill 1982 insofar as bank cheques are exempt from the proposed tax, which gives the banks unfair advantage over credit unions and building societies, because cheques from these societies are not exempt from the proposed tax? If this is correct, is the Treasurer able to do anything to rectify this inequity?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: — I did see some representations from the bodies mentioned by Senator Bjelke-Petersen. I would assume that the same representations have been made to the Treasurer and that he may be aware of the points that they have raised. I understand that that Bill is to be dealt with in the other place today. Pending the outcome of the debate on that Bill, I have no information to offer on behalf of the Treasurer. I will see whether there is any comment from him on Senator Bjelke-Petersen's question.

question.speaker: Bolkus Sen N.

talk.start.para: —I direct my question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer the Minister to an article in last weekend's Sunday Mail which stated:

question.para: Mr Tonkin said: 'The Prime Minister has indicated to me we have a better than even chance of getting a uranium enrichment industry ahead of Queensland.'
The article continued:
'After the Prime Minister's visit to South Australia, I am more convinced than ever South Australia can win this plant.'

I also refer to the Minister's comments last week when he criticised Labor Party senators for talking about the commencement date of a uranium enrichment plant. I refer the Minister to correspondence from the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia to members of parliament. The correspondence stated:
UEGA is not proposing at this time to proceed with the construction of an enrichment plant in Australia, nor even with a detailed feasibility study.
I also refer to the same group's correspondence to the Canberra Times in which it said:

There is no firm proposal to establish an enrichment industry in Australia at this time. UEGA has merely advised the Australian Government of the preferred technology to be used as a basis for further studies and investigations. Whether or not a uranium enrichment industry is established--

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Bolkus, you are giving a lot of information.
—Well, I think the Minister needs it. I am coming to the crux of my question.
—You had better soon come to it.
—UEGA goes on to say that--
—Order! Senator, I suggest you are giving a lot of information.

—I ask the Minister: In the light of information from UEGA, will he acknowledge that Dr Tonkin was in no position to receive the nod for the project from the Prime Minister? Will he also acknowledge that Dr Tonkin is embarking upon a program of misleading the South Australian public? In the interest of honesty in pre-election advertising, will the Minister acknowledge that there will be no jobs for Australians provided by this industry in the next decade?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —As to the last part of the question, let me say emphatically that I would not at all acknowledge that there will be no jobs in Australia for people in the next decade from a uranium enrichment plant. The fact is that there is a very great likelihood that Australia, in the course of the years ahead, will have a uranium enrichment plant and that will provide a very considerable number of jobs-thousands of jobs for construction and hundreds of jobs for operation. Let me put that completely at rest. The Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia was set up to do a number of things. First, it was to answer the question whether there would be markets for the product of an enrichment plant if Australia constructed one. It answered by saying yes, in the 1990s and beyond. The second question was: Would Australia have the technology and capacity to run such a plant? UEGA answered yes, emphatically. Then the group was put to work to study which, of three kinds of technology-gaseous diffusion, the centrifuge process and chemical exchange, or Chemex-would be preferred. The group reached the conclusion that the centrifuge process would be best. It then looked at the preferred technologies for use in the centrifuge approach and said that the Urenco-Centec process would be most acceptable. The group has now reported back. The Government having accepted in principle the centrifuge approach and the Urenco-Centec process, UEGA needed authority to proceed further with discussions on technology and, above all, as to marketability. This would take place with not only the European countries involved in Urenco-Centec but also Japan and other countries. Thus, the investigation is moving step by step towards a final decision, which will be made by government. UEGA itself is simply doing the investigation and making recommendations. I believe that it is fair to say, on the evidence that has come forward so far concerning the likelihood of markets and the selection of technology, that Australia has a very good chance of establishing a uranium enrichment plant. Secondly, the UEGA people have said that the two preferred locations are South Australia and Queensland. They are equally preferred. The enthusiasm on the part of the Premier of South Australia to get such an industry is to be commended.

answer.para: I find it extraordinary that the Labor Party should be opposed to the establishing of an enrichment plant; or are we to find tomorrow that Mr Bannon has changed his mind as he purports to have done concerning Roxby Downs? Labor is opposed to the enrichment proposal and is trying to white ant the situation because it understands that the public of South Australia is very keen indeed to get such an industry. The public knows that the industry is working well in other countries, that it provides good jobs, is safe from the point of view of health and can be of great benefit to South Australia. The public should listen to the knockers in the Labor Party and recognise their actions as a death knock on the part of that party.

talk.start.para: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Health whether he saw the statement made last week by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots calling for the banning of smoking on domestic airliners because of the cumulative and deleterious effects on the health of pilots. Is the Minister aware of the world-wide movement by governments to legislate for the rights of non-smokers who are, by the way, the majority, to enjoy clean and unpolluted air in public places? Since airliners are pressurised to a cabin altitude of 8, 000 feet, and therefore a lowered oxygen tension exists, are the hazards of cigarette smoke inhalation thereby potentiated? Is the Minister aware of any research into the effects of cigarette smoke at lower oxygen tensions?

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —I am aware of statements on the subject made last week by pilots' representatives. Senator MacGibbon attributed the statement to the Australian Federation of Air Pilots and that is probably correct. The pilots are concerned about the effects of smoking in aircraft and have made certain proposals. I am also aware of moves in some States to do away with tobacco sponsorship of certain events. I have noted the interest in Western Australia at the present time in the objection of the cricket authorities to a proposition that they should not accept tobacco sponsorship. Senator MacGibbon is correct in saying that non-smokers represent a majority in the community. Although he did not include it in his question, I must say that for non-smokers it is not always possible to obtain a non-smoker's seat in aircraft, which is a point of some concern. I think the honourable senator is correct when he asserts that pressurisation of aeroplanes does result in oxygen tension less than that which applies at sea level. It is therefore correct that there would be a lower arterial oxygen concentration for those who fly in pressurised cabins. It would be reasonable to assume that the effects of cigarette smoke would be potentiated in that circumstance.

answer.para: If the Australian Federation of Air Pilots can make a convincing case that health issues do arise as a result of smoking in aircraft, I think Ministers would want to take that on board. I will refer to the Minister for Health the matter raised by Senator MacGibbon as it may be something which can be put appropriately to the National Health and Medical Research Council for further study. I finish by reminding honourable senators that it is the policy of this Government, as laid down by the Government some years ago, to encourage less smoking in Australia. That remains the policy.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. It concerns the idiotic proposal to build a second runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport to ease congestion of air traffic over Sydney. Would not this objective be more readily achieved by giving the city a second airport to serve commuter and domestic services, as is the case in every other major world city of which I can think? Why has the World War II bomber base at Schofields, which is on a major highway and a major railway line and which has enough room for runways as large as those in Perth and Adelaide, not been considered, especially since it is still an operational airport? Is it a fact that the Royal Australian Navy, which controls the Schofields field, uses it for less than a dozen flights a week on average? Has the statement in the report of the Major Airport Needs of Sydney Committee that use of Schofields would interfere with Royal Australian Air Force traffic at Richmond been seriously tested in view of the enormous mass of air space available to the RAAF to the north of Richmond? Will the Government take some early action to answer the questions of those many people in the aviation industry in New South Wales who want to know why the Schofields option has so far been excluded?

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —In light of the statement from the Minister for Aviation, which outlined this matter at an earlier time, and of the detail which Senator Mason brings to the attention of the Senate, I think the best course to adopt is to ask for his question to go on notice. I will undertake to have it referred to the Minister.

—I ask the Minister for Social Security whether he has any intention of introducing in this session a Bill to rectify the unintended consequences of applying the loss of earnings provisions to sickness benefit applicants in line with the legal opinion which he got from the Attorney-General 's Department and which has resulted in many people being unable to receive sickness benefit. Is the Minister aware that if such legislation is not introduced as a matter of urgency there will in fact be thousands of people, on his own admission, who will be excluded from sickness benefit, including pharmaceutical concessions on their health cards?

answer.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —I advised the Senate last week, I think, that I was seeking advice on this matter from my Department-as far as I know it is not yet to hand- and I had not thought that legislation would be introduced during the current session. I also advised the Senate last week that the position is that people who may be rendered ineligible for sickness benefit because they have not lost income due to sickness as they were not in fact in receipt of income at the time of becoming sick may seek the assistance of my Department in the form of special benefit. The advice I have had from my Department is that in a very substantial proportion of cases where there is a problem because there was no loss of earnings special benefit is payable.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask: Is it a fact that the rate of wages growth in the United States of America over the past year has been about 6 per cent and in both West Germany and Japan it has been about 4 per cent, while the comparable figure for Australia is 15.2 per cent for the year ended June 1982? Is it also a fact that the average rate of inflation in member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development is 7.8 per cent and for our major trading partners it is about 6.5 per cent-the rate in the United States being 5.9 per cent, in West Germany 5.1 per cent and in Japan 3.1 per cent-against an annualised inflation rate of 12.3 per cent for Australia based on figures just released for the September quarter? What do these figures reveal about the relationship between wages growth and inflation, and what are the implications for Australia's level of competitiveness on world markets and its future as a trading nation?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: — I am not able to confirm the various figures mentioned by Senator Crichton-Browne, although I think in general terms we would accept that there are very great differences between the countries that he has mentioned and our own. The rate of wages growth in Australia and in some of the countries that are our major trading partners would be of the order indicated by Senator Crichton-Browne, but Australia's inflation rate is now seriously out of line with the rates of our trading partners. The effect of this and the need for the restraint of inflation are obvious, if we are to maintain our international competitive position and thereby retain or develop strong economic activity. Employment levels, of course, are affected by these things. Restraint on the part of Australians will be required in the future with regard to wage and salary increases. Most particularly, I refer to those who have received substantial wage increases over the past year or so. I will look at the figures mentioned by Senator Crichton-Browne and if there is any further information I can give on the relativities I will see that that is done. I make the general comment that our inflation rate is now seriously out of line with those of countries with which we would expect to be trading.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General and it relates to the revelations of the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union regarding the failure of this Government to utilise existing law in acting against bottom-of-the-harbour tax evasion between 1976 and 1982. Now that charges against Mr Massie and Mr Bercove of the Perth Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office have been investigated and found proved, when can we expect a full investigation of the performance of those higher up the tree who were roundly criticised by Mr Costigan or who have since been shown to have been knowingly involved in this extraordinary failure of administration? Finally, and in particular, I ask: When can we expect an investigation of the circumstances surrounding the meeting between Senator Durack, Mr Neaves and Mr O'Donovan at which the adequacy of the existing law was discussed-which meeting was admitted by the Attorney-General at the hearing of Estimates Committee A on 13 September to have taken place, the existence of which meeting was also confirmed in a subsequent letter from Mr Neaves to the Chairman of Estimates Committee A on 11 October, and for which meeting, despite the fact that two of the most senior bureaucrats of the country were present, no record as to date, time, place or subject matter appears now to be available?'

answer.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —The preface to that question referred to the revelations of the Costigan report that there was a failure to utilise existing law. It may be pertinent in that regard to note that, with the appointment of somebody to prosecute the case that was the subject of particular attention in the Costigan report, the finding of counsel was that indeed further evidence has to be obtained. As I think is known, the evidence is currently being gathered together . As to the detailed matter of what other action might be taken with respect to any deficiencies within the Department, I will refer that to the Acting Attorney -General for his consideration and reply. But my recollection of the comment on the meeting between Senator Durack, Mr Neaves and Mr O'Donovan referred to in the latter part of the question is that there was no written record and indeed that the precise time of the meeting is not known. I do not think that there is much prospect of any more detailed information coming forward with respect to that meeting. I will ask the Acting Attorney-General to make further inquiries about that matter.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it a fact that the inflation rate which was announced yesterday carries the impact of new government charges in two Budgets instead of the traditional one, as was stated in an Age article today? Does this mean that the real rate of inflation is better than the figures indicated?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: —The Australian Statistician has changed his collection procedures so that many of the recent increases in government taxes and charges, including some of the price effects of the Commonwealth Budget measures, have been recorded earlier than would have been the case in the past. This bringing forward of the bad news as compared with last year means that the September quarter result slightly overstates the underlying rate of inflation. The Department of the Treasury estimates that the Commonwealth's Budget measures contributed 0.15 percentage points to the 3.5 per cent increase in the September quarter. Another point to note is that over the last year the Government has introduced major changes in the method of financing health services and has placed an increased emphasis on indirect taxation as a means of financing its Budget. Both of these developments have had a major impact on the inflation rate as measured by the consumer price index.

answer.para: If the Government had not made these changes the measured inflation rate over the year to September would have run at slightly over 10 per cent. If allowance were made for increases in State indirect taxation the underlying rate would be lower still. I note that Senator Sir John Carrick said he would obtain information, if possible, with regard to the implications of State increases in this CPI. If these measures had not been implemented the Budget deficit would have been several hundreds of millions of dollars higher. I suppose one has to take into account the way in which we will finance a deficit and whether, when doing so, it has some implications for consumer price index figures. As I have said, there was a change in the method of collection to the degree that I have mentioned.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister, in his electorate talk on 26 September, claimed that the tax recoupment legislation was necessary to finance next month's so- called tax cuts, which could be more accurately described as next month's tax indexation. Since then the Prime Minister has weakly caved in by amending the legislation to cancel the obligation to pay of some vendor shareholders and deferring the obligation of others, thereby ensuring that a negligible amount of tax will be paid this year or perhaps ever. How will the tax cuts be paid for, or does the Government plan to cancel them as it did in 1977?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —The Senate will have the opportunity in the immediate days ahead of ensuring that the tax cuts legislation is passed and that the public gets the benefit of those tax cuts. The legislation will ensure that vendor shareholders covered by this recoupment tax will pay their tax, and that will be that. It will ensure that in so doing there is the minimum possible disturbance to employment opportunities in Australia. I would have thought that this was an eminently respectable and sensible way. debate.title: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

speech.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —by leave-This statement is about the ninth report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I shall touch briefly on the history of the matter. On 9 June 1978 the Senate referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs a resolution to establish a committee to maintain a watching brief on all Bills introduced into Parliament for the purpose of highlighting provisions which might be considered to interfere with the individual rights of persons or subject them to the exercise of undue delegations of power. In November 1978 the Committee issued its report on the scrutiny of Bills proposal and recommended the establishment of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

speech.para: The proposal was subject to considerable debate in the Senate and was given consideration by the Government. A Government response was made to the Committee 's recommendation on 22 November 1979. That statement indicated that the Government would not support the Committee's recommendation. I will quote in part from the statement which was put down at that time. It stated:

The Government is at one with the Senate Committee in its concern to protect the personal rights and liberties of the individual, and to ensure that there is no inappropriate delegation of legislative power or avoidance of adequate Parliamentary scrutiny of the exercise of legislative power.

However, the Government indicated that for a variety of reasons it did not think that it was appropriate to proceed in the way that the Senate Committee had recommended. The reasons for opposing the Committee's establishment included the reason that the proposal amounted to a new element in the legislative process, one which had the potential to distort and lengthen the present arrangements. Secondly, the Government believed it was the responsibility of each member and senator to ensure that legislation did not trespass unduly on individual rights and liberties and the establishment of a committee to perform this function would, in effect, delegate to a few the primary responsibility of the Parliament as a whole. The third reason was that the Government's legislation would or could be unnecessarily delayed.

In addition it was pointed out that there were other opportunities-at the time the Government thought they were ample-for the examination of legislation which comes before the Parliament to ensure that interests are protected and that such matters are brought to attention either before or after the introduction of legislation into the Parliament. It would be known to most honourable senators that the Senate decided that, notwithstanding the Government's attitude at that time, it would proceed on an experimental basis to have a scrutiny of Bills through the existing Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. In accordance with the recommendation, counsel were retained and the Committee has for a period been proceeding very much in accordance with the original recommendation.

The Government is as pleased as the next man to learn from experience. In light of the experience of the actual working of the Committee, the Government now takes a different attitude to the proposal which is before us and which is to be considered, I understand, later this week. In fact, experience has shown that the Committee has not caused inconvenience to the Government's legislative program. Indeed, many of its recommendations have been readily accepted by the Government. It is perhaps coincidental that I had the conduct of a good deal of the legislation which was the subject of comment by the Committee in its early days, as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in this place. Quite a number of items of legislation involving the rural industries were subject to amendment following matters which had been drawn to the Government's attention and the Senate's attention by the Standing Committee exercising its scrutiny of Bills function. So there has been a demonstration, in terms of amendments accepted by the Government and subsequently by the Senate, that there is a function to be performed in this area.

In addition, on behalf of the Government I wish to acknowledge that there has been a hidden flow-through effect into the departments. The very existence of the Committee is causing officials to think more closely about provisions in legislation concerning personal liberties and the delegation of legislative power and parliamentary scrutiny. So one of the other predicted effects of the Committee's existence has come about; namely, there has been a heightened awareness, in the pre-legislature stage of legislative preparation, of the sorts of principles with which the Committee is concerned.

So in light of that experience the Government would propose, when the matter comes on for consideration, to support the continuance of the scrutiny of Bills function. That will involve the establishment of a new committee. The Government will be prepared to support that. We shall support the reference to the Standing Orders Committee, and without commitment to the detail of the proposed Standing Order, support its being considered at that level, with a report back to the Senate. So in light of the operation of the Committee the Government has reconsidered the stance which it formerly took and is now taking a supportive and positive stance with respect to the proposal.

As a person who was involved in this proposition first as a senator in the early days of the consideration of the proposal by the Senate Committee and subsequently as a member of the Government when the Government had to consider its attitude to the proposal, I should like to say in this, as in so many elements of parliamentary and political life, the value and the success of any proposal is, in part at least-but in very large part, in my view-determined by the spirit in which the task is approached. There was a concern within the Government that this could be used as a means of delay, that it could be used for political purposes quite separate from the technical legislative purposes for which it was to be established. I am pleased to say that there has been no sign of that in the Committee's deliberations. I am sorry that that should call forth an attempt to interject from the Opposition Whip. It is a fact that at times politics bends the use to which things are put. The acceptance of this by the Goverment is an acceptance of the fact that to date this has operated as it was designed to operate, and it has been operated in the spirit in which it was intended to operate.

I make that point because, taking a very long established organ of the Senate, the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, it would be fair to say that is now so firmly rooted in the practices of the Senate that it is established that it should operate in a way which, again, I think, has been substantially non-political in character. It is worth noting in this regard that within the last two years there have been one or two occasions on which questions of politics have intervened in that and there has had to be some effort by the members of the Committee to ensure that it continues down its traditional path. I mention that because there is no point in ignoring the possible hooks in a proposal.

As one who was originally an enthusiastic supporter of this proposal, as one who then had, as a member of a government, to advance the view that we should not proceed with this, and as one who has now seen it in operation and succeeding in the way originally envisaged, I simply express my personal pleasure in that, and I express the hope that in this way we, the senators of the 1980s, are further advancing the usefulness of the Senate and its effectiveness as a legislative chamber. I would hope that this will be but one of the continuum of steps that we would all wish to see taken in the advancement of parliamentary life in Australia.

speech.speaker: Missen Sen A.J.

talk.start.para: —by leave-I would like to welcome the gracious statement which the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) has just made and to support his remarks. As Chairman of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee which has been operating now for some nine months and which has presented some 15 reports to the Parliament, I make the point that members of the Committee have appreciated both the reaction which we have seen to the Committee's activities and the response which the Government has made to many of the matters which have been raised by it. Many of the things I have raised are not matters which the Committee considers necessarily calls for change. But very often there is need to draw the attention of the Senate to particular items in legislation so that the Senate can proceed and make a decision in the full knowledge of what is proposed.

speech.para: I think Senator Chaney was slightly modest-too modest-because my recollection is that originally this was Senator Chaney's idea. Certainly, it was because of his strong support that the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs looked at this proposal. So I am very pleased to see that the full circle has been made and that Senator Chaney is able to respond as the Minister concerned. I do not think it is being in any way critical of the Government for it to have an opportunity of seeing how this matter operates in practice and then deciding that in fact it can operate well. Naturally, government seems to be cautious in regard to ideas which come forward. I will not proceed any further. I understand that this matter is to come up for debate later in the week on the motion for the adoption of the Committee's report. If the motion were adopted, the Committee would be set up with a separate membership and would not operate, as it does at the moment, with the membership of the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee. Those matters can be discussed further when we are debating the motion for the adoption of the report. However, I want to say that we, as members of the Committee, welcome the Government's response to this proposal and commend the Minister on his statement.

speech.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talker.name: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
talker.role: Minister for National Development and Energy)

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave for the second reading speeches to be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TAX (VEHICLE REGISTRATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

This Bill is part of a package of 4 Bills. Together the Bills will correct some deficiencies in the existing machinery and liability provisions of the law relating to stamp duties and taxes imposed in the Australian Capital Territory, including Jervis Bay. The changes proposed are generally in line with existing arrangements in the States and the Northern Territory. The proposed amendments will extend the exemptions granted in respect of new and transferred registrations of motor vehicles and trailers in the Territory.

The first of the amendments was foreshadowed in the Treasurer's statement of 7 June 1982. It will exempt from registration tax a transfer, in the course of winding up the affairs of a deceased person, of a motor vehicle formerly owned by that person. The exemption will apply to transfers to executors or administrators of an estate and to be a person who is beneficially entitled to the vehicle under a will or by virtue of the law of intestacy.

Transfers to a joint owner or joint owners of a vehicle that are consequential on the death of another joint owner will also be exempt. As foreshadowed in the Treasurer's announcement of 7 June, the broadened exemption will apply from 1 October 1981-the date from which the registration tax first applied. Amendments proposed in another Bill included in the package-the Australian Capital Territory Taxation (Administration) Amendment Bill 1982-will ensure that persons who have paid tax in the circumstances covered by this Bill before the Bill comes into force will be able to obtain a refund of the tax paid.

The second amendment proposed by the Bill will exempt a transfer of registration of a motor vehicle to a hire purchase company when the transfer takes place as a consequence of the repossession or voluntary return of the vehicle to the company by the hirer. A transfer under equivalent circumstances to a lessor engaged in a business of letting vehicles on lease is also to be made exempt. The new exemptions will apply in respect of applications for registration made on or after 14 October 1982.

The third amendment proposed by the Bill will extend an existing exemption applying to a registration in the name of a person carrying on a business in respect of which he or she is a licensed dealer under the A.C.T. Sale of Motor Vehicles Ordinance where the vehicle is held by the person as trading stock for re-sale in the course of the business. At present, the transfer of an A.C.T. registration to a motor vehicle dealer elsewhere in Australia-for example a N.S. W. dealer in Yass or Queanbeyan-in the course of carrying on business as a licensed dealer is subject to tax.

The amendment proposed will extend the exemption to dealers licensed in a State or in the Northern Territory if, in the dealer's own State or Territory, there is an equivalent exemption for A.C.T. dealers. In this regard, the Prime Minister has written to the Premier of New South Wales on the question of the possible granting of reciprocal exemption in that State. Explanations of technical aspects of this Bill and of the other Bills in the package are contained in an explanatory memorandum that is being made available to honourable senators. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TAX (INSURANCE BUSINESS) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

This Bill will ensure that premiums on insurance in respect of an employer's liability at common law for an injury to or death of an employee are exempt from tax. Under the Workmen's Compensation Ordinance employers in the Territory are required to take out insurance with an approved insurer in respect of their liabilities under that Ordinance and at common law for an injury or death of an employee. Existing provisions of the Australian Capital Territory Tax (Insurance Business) Act exempt premiums payable by an employer on a policy of insurance against his or her liability under the Ordinance. That exemption is accepted as applying to exempt the full amount of a premium under a single policy of insurance covering both a liability under the Ordinance and one at common law. The amendment proposed by the Bill will exempt premiums payable under a separate policy of insurance taken out in respect of a common law liability only. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY STAMP DUTY AMENDMENT BILL 1982

This Bill proposes to exempt from stamp duty certain conveyances of freehold or leasehold land to or from a trustee in circumstances where the beneficial interests in the property remain unchanged. The Australian Capital Territory Stamp Duty Act imposes duty on a transfer of, or an agreement to transfer, freehold or leasehold land situated in the Territory and on a transfer of a marketable security that is registered in a register kept by a company in the Territory. The first of the amendments proposed by this Bill will exempt from duty a conveyance made in consequence of the appointment or retirement of a trustee or of other change in trustees in order to vest the property in the trustees for the time being entitled to hold it. The second will apply in circumtances where a person purchases land in his or her own name with funds provided by another. The present law applies in these circumstances to impose duty on both the transfer of an interest in land to the trustee under the imputed trust arising in relation to this type of arrangement, and also on the transfer from the trustee to the person beneficially entitled to that interest.

Under the amendment proposed the second of the transfers involved in arrangements of this type-the transfer of the land from the trustee to the person who provided the purchase money-is to be exempted from duty.

The final new exemption proposed by the Bill will apply with respect to conveyances from a trustee to a beneficiary in the trust. The exemption will be subject to the conditions that the conveyance is not made for valuable consideration and that it does not consistitute a breach of trust. It is also to be a requirement for the exemption that the property the subject of the conveyance was acquired by the trustee by virtue of an instrument upon which duty has been paid or on which duty is not payable. The exemptions, which will be subject to safeguards against abuse, will apply with respect to instruments effected on or after 14 October 1982. Further amendments proposed by the Bill will make broadly similar transfers of marketable securities subject to antiavoidance safeguards of the kind that are to be applied in connection with the proposed exemptions for transfers of land. These amendments will also apply with respect to instruments effected on or after 14 October 1982. I commend this Bill to the Senate.
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TAXATION (ADMINISTRATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

This Bill is the last of the package of Bills designed to correct deficiencies in the machinery and liability provisions of the law relating to Australian Capital Territory stamp duties and taxes. The first of the amendments proposed by the Bill relates to situations where an agreement to transfer freehold or leasehold land is rescinded before the transfer takes place. Under the Australian Capital Territory Stamp Duty Act duty is payable on either an agreement to transfer land or the transfer itself. Commonly the duty is paid on the agreement. As the law presently stands there is no authority to refund duty paid on an agreement when an agreement is rescinded or annulled so that a transfer does not take place. The amendment proposed will introduce refund provisions to accommodate this situation. The amendment, which will incorporate necessary safeguards, will apply in respect of agreements entered into on or after 14 October 1982.

A second amendment will apply to transfers to give effect to a partition or division of interests in marketable securities held jointly or in common by two or more persons. At present, stamp duty is payable on the unencumbered value of marketable securities transferred under arrangements of this type, even though there may be no increase in the value of the parties' interest in the securities in consequence of the division. The amendment proposed will apply in these circumstances, with effect from 14 October 1982, to exclude from duty on the relevant transfer, the value of the beneficial interest held by the transferee in the marketable securities prior to the partition or division of those securities. Other substantive amendments proposed by the Bill are complementary to amendments proposed by other Bills included in the package. Included in these are the previously mentioned refund provisions consequential on the proposed amendments to vehicle registration tax in the Territory and provisions relevant to safeguards mentioned in relation to certain stamp duty amendments contained in the package. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
PAY-ROLL TAX (TERRITORIES) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1982

This Bill will raise the level of the general exemption from pay-roll tax applicable to the Australian Capital Territory. The Treasurer and the Minister for the Capital Territory announced the proposed increase on 2 August 1982. The exemption is to be raised from $80,400 to $120,000 per annum. The higher level will apply from 1 September 1981, thus providing an exemption for 1981-82 of $ 113,400 on a full-year basis. The last increase applied from 1 January 1981 when the exemption was brought up to $80,400 in line with that allowed in New South Wales. New South Wales has since increased its exemption level to $120,000 per annum, with effect from 1 September 1981.

The maximum exemption allowable in monthly returns will increase fom $6,700 to $10,000 and, in conformity with the existing rules for the phasing out of the maximum annual exemption, will be reduced at the rate of $2 for every $3 by which the wages for the month exceed $10,000. There will be no exemption once the monthly pay-roll reaches $25,000. As a general rule, the new exemption will first apply to returns for the month in which this Bill receives the Royal Assent but end-of-year adjustments will ensure that the benefits are in all cases back-dated to 1 September 1981. From the day on which the provisions of the Bill come into operation an employer paying wages of $2,250 or less a week will not be required to register for ACT pay-roll tax purposes.

As foreshadowed in the 2 August statement, further amendments proposed by the Bill will enable future increases in the general exemption level to be prescribed by regulation. This procedure will enable earlier adjustments in the ACT exemption level than have been possible in the past. Explanations of technical aspects of the Bill are contained in an explanatory memorandum that is being made available to honourable senators. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
