debate.title: AUSTRALIAN BICENTENNIAL ROAD DEVELOPMENT TRUST FUND BILL 1982

proctext.para: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick) read a first time.

speech.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talker.name: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
talker.role: Minister for National Development and Energy)

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave for the second reading speech to be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to establish the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund from which an estimated $2.5 billion will be provided over the next six years to upgrade Australia's roads by 1988-our Bicentennial year.

This funding is additional to and separate from the $3.65 billion provided to the States under the Roads Grants Act 1981. Together, both Programs will provide the impressive sum of $914 million in 1982-83, rising to $1,208 million in 1983- 84 for all categories of roads.
This is the biggest drive to boost road construction and improvement ever mounted in this country. The Programs' contribution to national growth and prosperity will benefit all Australians.

The object of the new Program is to fund national, arterial and local road projects of significance that will develop the Australian road network to a high standard. The Program will facilitate the reliable and efficient carriage of traffic. It will enhance the safety of Australian roads.
The ABRD Program will address four main areas of need:

The national highway system will be brought to a high standard to meet our growing transport requirements for the efficient movement of people and goods around Australia. The Program will ensure the completion of a sealed, and virtually flood-free national highway system.
The construction of developmental roads, including some in remote areas and roads of national tourism importance, will be accelerated.
Specific urban and rural arterial road projects will be funded, and where States so choose, assistance may be provided for approved urban public transport projects.
Local government authorities will be able to nominate local projects for inclusion in the program.
The ABRD Program will generate a number of important benefits:
Lives will be saved as a result of the improved safety on our roads.
Communications between the States (and regional areas) will be enhanced as a result of better national highways and arterial roads.
Considerable savings will be made in vehicle and transport operating costs.
Savings will be made in private and commercial travelling time.
Travellers in more remote areas will benefit from reductions in dust hazards and reduced delays due to flooding.

8,000 jobs will be provided in the road construction industry alone. Moreover it is expected that at least 20,000 jobs will be provided in both direct and indirect employment throughout the ABRD Program's duration.
The Government considers that this Program will be a tremendous tribute to the 200 years of our nation's development. Roads affect every Australian.

Road transport accounts for almost 80 per cent of our domestic freight tonnage and 90 per cent of passenger kilometres travelled. Since roads are important to every Australian, it is appropriate that the Australian Bicentennial Authority has fully endorsed the ABRD Program. It will leave an enduring legacy of the Bicentenary to all future Australians.
The Commonwealth acknowledges that the level of its funding of roads in recent years has not kept pace with increases in road construction costs.

While Roads Grants Act funding beyond 1984-85 has yet to be determined, the Government will need to give consideration to the level of road funding to be provided for the next five-year period 1985-86 to 1989-90 well before the conclusion of the current 5 year program.

However, the Fraser Government has resolved to make a major investment in our road network-a national asset of critical importance. The ABRD Program is the Government's response to this important need. A recent Commonwealth/State study of national highway deficiencies concluded that at the former levels of funding by the Commonwealth, it would take until well beyond the year 2000 to bring our national highways up to an acceptable standard.

The urgency of the problem and the need for additional funds was made clear to the Minister for Transport and Construction when he undertook a tour of inspection of the Bruce Highway between Rockhampton and Townsville earlier this year.

He indicated at the time that the condition of that road was, to put it mildly, totally inadequate for a national highway which was serving an area undergoing such rapid development. A joint Commonwealth/Queensland study later confirmed this assessment.

The establishment of a Trust Fund has been adopted for the ABRD Program to ensure that all funds raised from the fuel surcharge are used for projects approved as part of the ABRD Program and for no other purpose.
The Fund will receive all revenue generated from the surcharge on motor spirit and diesel fuel excise, less applicable rebates. All interest earned on Fund investments will accrue to the Fund.
The special surcharge was proposed at last June's Premiers' Conference and supported by all States and the Northern Territory.

As noted earlier total Commonwealth road funding in 1982-83 will now amount to some $914 million. This represents an increase of $229 million or 33 per cent when compared with road funds allocated in 1981-82.

In 1983-84, when the ABRD Program is fully operational, Commonwealth expenditure under both the ABRD and Roads Grants Programs will total an estimated $1,208 million. That will represent an increase of $523 million or 76 per cent over 1981-82 road expenditures.
These increases are far in excess of recent movements in road building costs.

The special ABRD surcharge on motor spirit and diesel fuel excise is being phased in to allow State and Northern Territory road authorities time to gear up for the substantial increase in construction activity that will result from the Program.
One cent per litre has been applied since 17 August 1982 and this will rise to two cents per litre from 1 July 1983.
The surcharge will be discontinued after 31 December 1988, and as provided for in this Bill, the Trust Fund will be closed down one year later following the acquittal of any outstanding commitments.

While the impact of the ABRD Program on our road network will be substantial and appreciated by all travellers, the cost of the surcharge to individual motorists and road transport operators will be relatively small.

For example, even at the two cents per litre level, an average motorist travelling 15,000 km per year can expect to pay only 67 cents extra per week. For the driver of a typical 38 tonne truck, the 2 cents surcharge will mean that a Sydney-Melbourne round trip will cost an extra $18.
Significantly, the response that the Minister for Transport and Construction has already received from road authorities, local government organisations and others has been very positive.

It has confirmed the belief that the Australian people will accept an increase in Government charges and costs if they can clearly see where the money is going and know that it is to be spent for such a constructive purpose of enormous economic and social benefit to the community.
ABRD funds will be allocated between the various road categories in the following proportions:
In 1982/83, national roads 40%, urban arterial roads 30%, rural arterial roads 15%, local roads 15%.
For the year 1983/84 and beyond, national roads 42%, urban arterial roads 30%, rural arterial roads 16%, local roads 12%.

Notwithstanding these percentages, a State or the Northern Territory may seek and receive approval to transfer funds between the urban and rural arterial roads categories, or from both to either of these categories into national roads .
The Bill does not provide for transfers from the local roads category.

On a category by category basis, this will mean that in total some $396 million will be available for upgrading our national roads in 1982/83, rising to about $ 525 million in 1983/84. Similarly, some $317 million will be available for urban and rural arterial roads this financial year, increasing to approximately $448 million in the following year. Local road funds will be allocated a total of an estimated $200 million in 1982/83 and about $235 million the year after.

No set ratio will be used to apportion national road funds between the States and the Northern Territory. Rather, this money will be distributed in accordance with the requirement of achieving the basic Program objectives and national priorities, following consultation with the States and Northern Territory.

Developmental roads will also be eligible for assistance under the national roads category. Developmental roads are roads which are significant from the national point of view, for the development of particular industries and energy resources, including those in remote areas. Roads which facilitate international trade or commerce, or tourist activities may also be classified as developmental roads.

ABRD funds allocated for the urban arterial, rural arterial and local roads' categories will be distributed between States and the Northern Territory in accordance with current funding relativities. Local road funds in turn, will be apportioned within the States in accordance with principles to be developed for this Program.

On a State by State basis, indicative figures suggest that, taking into account both the ABRD Program and the ongoing Roads Grants Program, the following increases in Commonwealth funding will be provided:
N.S.W., a 34 per cent increase this financial year and a 78 per cent increase in 1983/84 compared with the 1981/82 figure.
Victoria, increases of 34 per cent and 77 per cent respectively.
Queensland, 35 per cent and 81 per cent.
South Australia, 30 per cent and 68 per cent.
Western Australia, 34 per cent and 77 per cent.
Tasmania, 29 per cent and 65 per cent.
and for the Northern Territory the respective expenditure increases will be 27 per cent and 62 per cent.

Turning to the arrangements which will apply to the administration of the ABRD Program, Honourable Senators will note that there are a number of significant changes when compared with the arrangements applying to the Roads Grants Program .

Firstly, as this Program approaches the upgrading of the road network from a national perspective, Commonwealth approval will be required for each ABRD project. Thus national priorities will be considered in the project approval process, and in general, projects will be significant in nature.

However, the Commonwealth's involvement will not be a heavy handed intrusion into State and Northern Territory affairs. On the contrary, projects will be identified by way of close consultation between the respective governments and the approval process will primarily be a vehicle to ensure that the objectives of the Program are being effectively pursued. Consultations with the States and Northern Territory are already underway to identify projects for inclusion in the Program.

Another departure from practice under the Roads Grants Act is that this Bill provides for separate allocations to be made for urban arterial roads and rural arterial roads. This will enable appropriate attention to be devoted to roads in urban areas where the majority of Australia's population lives.

In this regard the Bill also permits the States and the Northern Territory, if they wish, to expend part of their urban arterial roads allocation on urban public transport capital works. This acknowledges that urban public transport services have the potential to take considerable pressure off urban arterial roads.

To maximise the benefits of the ABRD Program on our road system, a provision has been included in the legislation making it necessary for the State and Northern Territory governments to maintain, in real terms, the level of road funding from their own resources. Where a State proposes urban public transport projects they will be required to maintain their own spending on capital works in this area.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics Implicit Price Deflator for Private Non- dwelling Construction will be used, amongst other pertinent factors, in determining whether the States and Northern Territory have in fact, maintained their expenditure in real terms. However, if a State or the Northern Territory allows its expenditure on roads or urban public transport to fall behind in real terms in a given year, and subsequently fails to compensate for the shortfall with an equivalent increase in the following year, then its allocation may be offset by withdrawal of an equal amount of its ABRD funds.

This will ensure that real improvements are made to our road system, and Commonwealth funds are not used to allow States to diminish their continuing financial responsibilities for their own roads and public transport services.

Furthermore, the Government is determined that all taxpayers will receive full value for each dollar they are being asked to pay. With this in mind the existing tendering requirement for national road construction works is being extended in the ABRD Program to cover urban and rural arterial road categories and urban public transport projects. It is only in a competitive environment that we can be sure of getting maximum value from this massive investment in construction.

Highlighting the Bicentennial nature of the Program, all ABRD projects will be marked by appropriate Bicentennial signs. This will guarantee that all Australians will see where their funds are being spent. The signs will also have the effect of reminding Australians about the Bicentenary and the important contribution roads make to the economic and social life of our nation.
The Minister for Transport and Construction will be reporting to the Parliament annually on Trust Fund transactions and on the progress made on approved projects.

I have canvassed the more significant elements of the Bill before the Senate today. The remaining provisions are similar to those contained in the current Roads Grants legislation, the most recent Act of which was passed through the Senate in the preceding autumn session of Parliament. The Explanatory Memorandum that has been circulated describes in detail all the features of the Bill.
Therefore, I do not propose to deal further with any individual sections.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

debate.title: DIESEL FUEL TAXES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1982

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 21 October, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —During my remarks on this legislation last Thursday I made the point that the Government's claim that the new rebate would simplify administrative procedures was very suspect. The Government was calling on users of diesel fuel to apply for the rebate on a regular basis whereas under the old exemption procedures one had to apply only once. The burden of my criticism is that although the goverment claims that it will raise $161m through this legislation it is able to give no information whatsoever as to which sectors of the community will be called upon to meet this increased impost of $ 161m. In the meantime, while this legislation is being debated, all users of diesel fuel are paying for fuel at the full price.

speech.para: As various honourable senators have pointed out, that imposes considerable hardships on certain users right now. I pointed out that it seemed to us that there were three sectors of the community, in particular, which were large users of diesel fuel and which would be unfairly hit by this proposed legislation. I referred especially to local government, tourism and the baking industry. I will pursue my comments as to the effect of this legislation on local government.

It seems particularly stupid for the Government to remove the exemption for local government authorities and to replace it with a rebate. It has been impossible to find out the precise usage by local government authorities but there is no doubt that it is considerable. We have only to consider the list of suggested uses compiled by the Australian Council of Local Government Associations. Local councils obviously use fuels for heating generally- particularly for small community facilities such as infant welfare centres and public swimming pools; for heating used in sewerage treatment plants; for power generation, particularly in remote areas, and for emergency generation the need for which is very widespread today; for pumps, for irrigation networks and flood control; and for garbage disposal crushers. This equipment is frequently powered by diesel engines. Crematoriums and cemetery plants use diesel fuel to a great extent. In addition, there is the doubtful area of road construction. This tax will apply to off-road use and, as new roads are not, I guess, strictly speaking defined as roads until they are built, it would seem that new road construction would also be a target for this new and hidden tax.

In effect, the Government will take 6.155c a litre from local government and give back one cent a litre for the building of new roads. Is that not clever? The Government will take it with one hand but not give it back with the other. There is no doubt that under this new legislation local government will suffer considerably. It will impose a tax on local government activities at a time when we should be looking to local government to expand employment. It is the wrong sort of tax at absolutely the wrong time for the health of our economy.

The second category I referred to was tourism. I made the point that the tourist industry is a very large earner of foreign exchange. At a time when we have a deficit of about $10 billion on our current account we are imposing an additional tax on the tourist industry, which accounts for four per cent, or $ 949m of our total receipts on that account-with the effect that that has on the balance of payments. Yet the Government proposes to tax this vital industry. What equity is there in that? Presumably, the Government has very rightly exempted primary industry, on the basis that it is an important earner of foreign exchange but has not considered at all the tourist industry, which is also a very vital generator of foreign exchange for this country. We have received representations from people in the tourist industry who are involved in developing multimillion dollar tourist facilities on islands off the north Queensland coastline and are now wondering whether those facilities will be viable. So we believe that there is no equity in exempting primary industry and not at the same time exempting the tourist industry.

The third category I mentioned was the baking industry. I say only that baking facilities are a basic requirement in any society. I am astounded that the Government is considering imposing on bakers an extra cost which will undoubtedly be passed on immediately to consumers.

In my previous remarks I foreshadowed that on behalf of the Australian Democrats I will move at the Committee stage amendments to this legislation which will seek to exempt from the new rebate these three vital areas of our economy. The rebate represents a secret tax on vital sectors of the economic machine of this country. As I said earlier, these Bills are not impressive pieces of legislation. We are not convinced that they will ease the administrative load of the Department or make it any easier to detect abuses. I will be waiting with great interest to hear the closing comments of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) on this debate to see what possible justification he can put forward for the imposition of increased taxes on at least the three sectors of the economy that I have mentioned.

speech.speaker: Collard Sen S.J.

talk.start.para: — The Senate is dealing with the Diesel Fuel Taxes Legislation Amendment Bill 1982 and two related measures. It must be recognised by everybody that the legislation is designed to raise revenue for the Government. That has been the purpose of the exercise for many years now. The Australian Democrats, in their contribution to the debate, have more or less indicated that every Budget that is brought in is a negotiable document. They blithely say that they will not block Supply and traipse around the countryside with statutory declarations. Yet when we bring in a Budget document they seem to think that it is negotiable and try to deny the Government its methods of raising money.

speech.para: I suppose that to say there are anomalies in this legislation is quite arguable . It would be equally arguable that anomalies exist in other revenue raising legislation. I am quite sure that I could make a pretty good case for my not paying income tax. I do not imagine that I would get much sympathy from honourable senators, least of all from the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney). So I think one must point out at the outset that these are revenue raising Bills and have been such for some considerable time. As such, they are not negotiable-even though each and every one of us would have some sympathy with some of the matters raised by Senator Siddons. We might feel even more strongly concerning them, but must accept the purpose of these measures, debate them and go along with them.

The Government has recognised that for some sections of the community, the price received for their product bears no relationship to the cost incurred. I refer particularly to primary industry, the fishing industry, the timber industry and, to a lesser extent, to the mining industry. The Government has taken that into consideration and in geting rid of the exemptions has allowed a rebate. When I debated the report of the Woodward Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Australian Meat Industry I indicated that regrettably, in a country such as Australia, which has so much going for it, some members of our society seem to wish to cut right across the norm and make a quick buck no matter at whose expense it is derived. Thus we saw practised, irrespective of the damage that could be done, meat substitution that put into jeopardy our whole meat export trade.

We have seen the same type of approach taken to tax avoidance and evasion and thus have had to bring in legislation to recoup moneys owing by those who have indulged in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes in order to avoid paying their dues to society. Most other people have no alternative in that regard. When we examined the situation with regard to the diesel exemption, we found that people were abusing the exemption and that a lot of revenue was lost to the Government. The Government introduced this Bill to provide a tightening up. The exemption certificates were discontinued. The rebate system is being introduced. It will tighten up the whole situation. It will prevent the abuses that have occurred in the past.

Senator Siddons spent some considerable time saying how badly off local government would be. I thought everybody in this chamber was aware of the fact that, under the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Bill 1982, local government will be allowed extra revenue for its road building programs. Instead of getting 10 per cent of the money available from the Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund, the Government is allowing local government 15 per cent to cover that contingency. It has been worked out that local government will not be any worse off. As I said at the outset, this is a revenue raising exercise by the Government. As such, it is not negotiable. A commendable case could be made out for anybody to find a way out of paying revenue to the Government of the day . This is one of the methods used to raise revenue. The Government has provided for those who, as I said, do not receive a price for their product which bears any relationship to the cost of producing that product. We have provided a rebate system. The sooner this legislation is passed, the sooner the rebate system will be put in train. Those people will be able to get back the money that they have paid over and above what they would normally pay. I support the Bill and I do not agree with the proposed amendments.

speech.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Collard and other Government speakers for the support that they have expressed for the Diesel Fuel Taxes Legislation Amendment Bill 1982. Senator Collard made a fairly fundamental point which does explain some of the unhappiness which has been expressed by other honourable senators. This, of course, is a revenue raising Bill. It is a Bill which does increase the amount of income which the Government is seeking to help to pay for the very greatly increased outgoings provided in the Budget. These outgoings flow across matters such as roads, which are of direct relevance to many fuel users. The Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program has been referred to. Of course, across the range of Government activities, whether we are looking at defence or my own portfolio of Social Security, substantial additional bills have to be met. My own Department has to spend in excess of some $1,500m plus to carry out the welfare aspects of its activities. That money has to be raised by taxes. For that reason, it is terribly easy for those who are opposing the Bill to point with horror at the fact that the Bill increases the imposts on some sections of the Australian economy. There is no avoiding the fact that taxing measures will do that unless there is a reduction in all forms of taxation. That is a course of action which was not open to the Government when preparing the current Budget .

speech.para: The debate has raised a series of matters. In deference to the fact that honourable senators have raised them, I wish to comment briefly on the concerns which have been expressed. One of the concerns will, of course, be met by the passage of this legislation that is, the delay which has occurred in the payment of rebates. Those users entitled to rebates have, since August, been awaiting the passage of this legislation to permit rebates to be processed. Once this legislation is passed through the Parliament, it will be possible to put in place the administrative measures required to ensure that the rebates are paid. Claim forms cannot be printed until the legislation has been passed. It is expected that the forms will be available within a few days of that date. Arrangements have been made for the forms to be distributed by oil company agents and fuel distributors. They also will be available at Australian Bureau of Customs offices throughout Australia. The completed application forms, together with the relevant invoices, will then have to be lodged with the diesel fuel rebate section of the Bureau of Customs in the capital city in the applicant's State of residence. The whole of the rebate program will be controlled through the Customs service's computer network. Since this scheme was announced on Budget night, the Customs service has been faced with the task of purchasing hardware, developing and testing the program and recruiting and training data processing officers. This involves a heavy workload in the initial stages. But it is expected that, once this is overcome, processing time will not exceed two weeks.

The matter of the effect on local government is the subject of one of the amendments which are to be moved and was also the subject of comment during the debate. As has been pointed out by Government senators in response, whilst local government will carry some of the impost of this revenue-raising measure it is a section of the economy which will be receiving considerable additional benefits in the Budget. In 1982-83, the total allocation for local roads under the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program and the ongoing roads program is expected to amount to about $200m-an increase of $39m or 24 per cent over last year's level. That increase will more than offset the additional excise charges which are unlikely to exceed about $10m in 1982-83. The Bureau of Transport Economics has roughly estimated that, combined, the extension of diesel fuel excise and the surcharge will add between one per cent and 2 per cent to road construction costs.

The benefits to local government will be greater in the next full financial year because, of course, it will get the full benefit of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program. There is a total allocation for local roads which is estimated at $235m, which is $73m or 46 per cent higher than the 1981-82 level. Of course, local government will also benefit from the increased general revenue assistance in the personal income tax sharing grants which will increase by about $75m or almost 21 per cent over last year's allocation, bringing the total assistance under that scheme to $1,783m since 1976-77. In other words, it is true that there will be some additional impost on local government because of this measure. That is more than offset by the various benefits which flow to local government from the recent Budget.

I should like to refer to the other particular points that are raised by Senator Siddons's amendment. Senator Siddons touched on this aspect during the second reading debate and it may shorten the debate in Committee if I mention why the Government does not support the proposed amendments. Senator Siddons proposes to move an amendment to include in the rebate scheme the provision of accommodation for other persons. The Bill already contains provisions for the payment of the rebate on diesel fuel used at residential premises except where the accommodation is run as a business so that hotels, motels and boarding houses are excluded. Of course, it is possible to point to any area of business activity and say that it ought to be subject to exclusion, as Senator Siddons has said with respect to the tourist industry. The more exclusions there are, of course, the more heavily the impost falls on those non-excluded sections of the economy. One could go on endlessly multiplying the categories of business which might, in order to encourage their activities, be exempt.
I must say I was somewhat tickled by the words used by Senator Siddons in the debate when this matter was before the Senate last Thursday. Senator Siddons said:
The Bill is just another example of a government masquerading as Father Christmas.

Of course, Senator Siddons is having his little go at being a Father Christmas through the amendments that he proposes to move. He is selecting some parts of the economy that he thinks would particularly benefit from exemption. He is endeavouring to show what a Father Christmas he would be with respect to them. I say again, as I have said in previous debates, that it is very easy for the Australian Democrats to propose benign amendments to taxation legislation which will lift the burden of taxation as it is terribly easy for them to support substantial additional expenditure. I am told that Senator Macklin, who is in the chamber now, attended a pensioners' meeting in Brisbane and cheerfully supported increases in the rates of pensions which would lift them to a very much greater proportion of average weekly earnings. The Australian Democrats take a luxury position; they sit there and demand increased expenditure and reduced taxation. I think it is important that at some stage those people who are interested in the Democrats, and perhaps in supporting them, should ask them to draw up something of a balance sheet of those increases and decreases that they seek. It is too easy to come into this place and urge that the impost be lifted from those sections of the community favoured by them.

The matter of the fishing industry was raised in particular by my colleague Senator Archer. It has been dealt with in the sense that the concern that he has for operators engaged in fishing-their not being able to use the claim procedure because of the operations that they are involved in and the long period that they are away and so on-has been dealt with satisfactorily and can be dealt with administratively. The admission of fishing co-operatives to the arrangements as parties which will be able to process claims on behalf of the fishermen should remove that difficulty. No amendment of the legislation is required to meet the concern which was the subject of representations by Senator Archer.

In the same way, reference was made during the debate, and representations were made prior to the legislation's coming into the Senate, on the possible differential effect of the impost on the iron ore producers in the Pilbara. A very careful examination of the Bill and a check with the Attorney-General's Department of the wording of the legislation have disclosed a situation in which the feared differential impact will not in fact apply. The definitions contained in the Bill are wide enough to ensure that the legislation can be applied in a uniform way to the various iron ore producers in the Pilbara.

There were queries about the amount of additional revenue that this measure will collect. They were raised by both Senator Walsh for the Opposition and Senator Siddons for the Australian Democrats. The Budget announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) was that the changed arrangements were estimated to yield a net increase in revenue of $161m in 1982-83 at the previously existing excise rate of 5.155c a litre and $176m in a full year. As far as the precise burden which will fall on different users is concerned, that can only be subject to estimate because there simply are no records available which would tightly indicate the amounts of fuel used by sectors of industry. In other words, no records are available to give in precise terms the burden which will be carried by any particular section of the economy.

Senator Walsh raised the possibility of dyed fuel being used. That matter has been raised over the years, not merely by the Opposition but also by many who have been concerned both at the incidence of abuse and at the desire to have access to fuel in appropriate circumstances. Organisations such as the Pastoralists and Graziers Association of Western Australia (Incorporated) have put it forward at meetings. I remember that it came up at one meeting in Meekatharra when Senator Walsh was in attendance. It is an issue that has been raised before and that has been considered. Under the old system of providing exemption for off-road use, there was a series of reasons why it was thought that that was not a practical approach. Of course, those reasons are no longer relevant, but to introduce that scheme now would undoubtedly complicate the physical handling arrangements of those who provide fuel and, indeed, the users of fuel who might require separate storage for the coloured fuel and the non- coloured fuel as they carry out activities some of which are exempt and some of which are not exempt. In addition, the sort of examination that would be required in a country the size of Australia suggests that as a policing measure it would have to be accompanied by substantial inspection facilities, which would be quite difficult. However, I note the suggestion which was made by Senator Walsh and which, as I have said, has been made on other occasions. I will refer it to the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr Peacock) for further and future consideration. I know that it would have support from some sections of the community.

I do not think there is anything further that I wish to say. Senator Archer raised the possibility of a further amendment to include the timber industry. It is quite clear that one could go on endlessly increasing the categories of exemption or the categories of those entitled to the rebate. This is a measure which is part of the Government's Budget. Whilst it is not a measure which will bring in billions of dollars, it will bring in some $160m. It is a significant measure and the Government does not see its way clear to interfere with its Budget in this respect or other respects which would have the effect of changing the Budget aggregates in a way which the Government does not believe would be in the interests of Australia.

talk.start.para: —I think Senator Archer's problems were mainly of confusion.

—The matter of the timber industry has already been subject to some adjustment to meet the representations which have been made. Any further adjustment would have to await an examination of the system in practice.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

speech.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: (1) That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Page 2, clause 5, proposed new section 164, sub-section (1), after paragraph (d ), add:
''; (e) in the operations of a local government body;
(f) in the provision of accommodation for other persons; or
(g) in baking''.
I ask that separate questions to be put on the consideration of each of the three sub-paragraphs of the amendment.

talk.start.para: —I support the request. In particular I draw the attention of the Committee to the fact that in respect of the baking of bread the diesel fuel tax will have an impost which will be felt throughout the length and breadth of the community, except by those people who make home made bread and there are not many of them left. However, it ought to be realised that there is a real possibility that if the request of Senator Siddons is not agreed to there could well be increases in the price of a loaf of bread, part of the staple diet. I think that, with bread being such a necessity of life, the proposition deserves the agreement of the Government. If we cannot obtain the agreement of the Government then I hope it will have the support of the Opposition so that the request can be forwarded to the House of Representatives for consideration.

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen P.A.

talk.start.para: —The Opposition has considerable sympathy with at least the first of the three sub-paragraphs of the request moved by Senator Siddons; that is, the one that relates to local government. I will say a bit more about that in a moment. As to sub-paragraphs (f) and (g), notwithstanding what Senator Harradine has just said, it seems to us that to say that we will exempt the baking industry and the accommodation industry, as proposed in Senator Siddons's request, is a completely arbitrary decision. I acknowledge that the decisions which have already been made by the Government as to who and who will not be exempt from this excise are probably equally arbitrary, but there is no clear, consistent or guiding principle, it seems to us, as to what should or should not be exempt. It is clear that local government -we have considerably more sympathy for it-is having a pea and thimble trick pulled on it by the Fraser Government. With much fanfare we have the announcement of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program which is to be financed by increased taxes on distillate generally. I am informed by the Local Government Association that local government's share in that extra money will be in the vicinity of only $1m and the extra tax imposed by the extension of the excise tax on distillate used by local government in an off-road capacity will cancel the benefit derived from the local government share of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund.

speech.para: However, there is one other consideration on which a firm blanket statement has been made by the Opposition; that is, that Budget measures will not be opposed in the Senate. Quite clearly, this is a Budget measure; it was announced on Budget night. Underpinning the general statement which the Australian Labor Party has made is the proposition that this Budget is Malcolm Fraser's Budget and he can live with it. I might say that the Opposition shares the sentiments and the assessment expressed by the Australian Democrats last week on another motion about the Prime Minister's penchant for misrepresenting the truth. If any amendments to this Bill were to be carried in the Senate there is little doubt that the truth of the matter and the significance of the amendments would be misrepresented by the Prime Minister. I am a little confused by the Australian Democrats' action in this case when it is juxtaposed with their action in respect of a second reading amendment last week. The second reading amendment to which I refer was in respect of the Drought Assistance (Primary Producers) Bill, which was not a Budget measure. The Australian Democrats did not support a second reading amendment about something which was not a Budget measure. They gave their reasons, which I have mentioned; that they believed the Prime Minister would misrepresent the facts, the truth. They are almost certainly right about that. I am confused as to why in that instance they took that view and in this case, on an amendment at the Committee stage of a Bill-which as we all know is more meaningful than a second reading amendment, if it is carried, because it does actually change the substance of the Bill-they have chosen to take a different course of action.

With some regret I state that the Opposition will not support the amendments whether they are put separately or conjointly. We have particular regrets in not supporting the first of the amendments-the one which relates to local governments-because, as I said, local government has had a pea and thimble trick pulled on it. But they are Budget measures. We gave a blanket statement of policy two months ago that Budget measures would not be blocked in the Senate. The Opposition feels obliged to abide by that statement.

speech.speaker: Thomas Sen A.M.

talk.start.para: —I wish to make a few remarks in relation to clause 5 of the Diesel Fuel Taxes Legislation Amendment Bill. In my opinion clause 5 is one of the worst worded clauses of a Bill that I have ever seen in my life. The amount of confusion it has created within the mining industry in particular would not be believed. First, I want to say a couple of words about the fishing industry. Senator Archer mentioned in his speech at the second reading stage of the Bill on Thursday that following representations by him, Senator Collard, Senator Withers and me, the Government had agreed to changes in the regulations with regard to the excise collection provisions. I thank the Government for that change. Until that happened there was a great deal of confusion about this in the fishing industry.

speech.para: I want to give an example of the sort of confusion that it can create, and still creates, in another industry altogether-the salt industry. There are many major salt producers in Western Australia. One of them, Dampier Salt Ltd, is the second largest in the world. In fact, it was the largest until the Mexican industry began just a few years ago. Because of the way in which clause 5 of the Bill is worded the industry is still uncertain as to how this fuel excise will be applied. Information that I have received from departments and Ministers indicates that when the salt is harvested from the evaporative pans it will be covered by the exemption provisions of the legislation; when the salt is carted from the pans to the washing plant it will be covered; but when the salt is carted from the washing pans to the storage area or the port it will not be covered. I can understand that. I guess it is reasonable to make that assumption . But the salt industry has put to me very strongly the point of view that when the salt is in storage at the port a draining or beneficiation process is going on, because a larger amount of water, bitterns and liquid is left in the salt after it has been through the washing process. The industry claims that this storage in fact is a form of beneficiation. I suppose the industry will be making representations to the Government after this Bill is passed.

I wish to reinforce the point of view which was put forward by Senator Walsh, Senator Archer and other speakers on Thursday with regard to the iron ore industry in the Pilbara. There are four producers there. It looked to us, and certainly to the industry, as though the Bill would disadvantage one of the producers there, Hamersley Iron Pty Ltd, to the tune of something like $2.2m, or up to $3.2m if it reached full production again of 48 million tonnes a year, as against the other three producers which will be exempt from the diesel excise with regard to the cartage of the iron ore from the mine site to the port. This is all to do with the understanding of the word 'beneficiation'. I thank the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) for the words he used in his summary of the second reading debate when he said that he and the Minister whom he represents had been to see the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and had obtained a ruling on this matter to say that my fears and the fears I have expressed to the Ministers and the Govenrment over the last five weeks are unfounded.

This really is an example of the messy framing of this Bill. The Bill is impossible to understand. I know that many other people at the margins who wish to have this matter interpreted will express concern. I understand from the Minister that departmental officers will be travelling around the mining industry and seeing people affected in other areas to try to explain just what the Bill means. I wish them the very best of British luck. It seems strange to me that the Government could not come up with a form of words which made the situation much more clear in the first place. This would have saved us and many other people a great deal of trouble.

speech.speaker: Macklin Sen M.J.

talk.start.para: —I support the amendment moved by Senator Siddons. I do not want to speak overlong about it but I do wish to raise an item in relation to local government. It seems to me to be absurd that we should seek to tax one level of government when today the Senate has received a Bill in relation to the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program. I am not quite sure about the estimate of $1m to which Senator Walsh referred, but in Queensland alone that program will involve in the vicinity of $3m. At the same time we are taking away through additional charges within this Budget an amount almost equal to that which will be given to local government under that Bill. Those figures have been given to me by the Local Government Association of Queensland, which, as probably most people would know, is not likely to be stocked very well by either the Australian Labor Party or the Australian Democrats. In fact, that group would be much more sympathetic to the Government. I believe its proposition is a very firm one. It raises the absurdity of the Federal Government giving with one hand and taking away with the other, and seeking to tax even further another arm of government. Local governments might be in some way appeased if they were allowed to levy taxes on the Commonwealth by way of rates, of which they lose massive amounts every year throughout Queensland. Of course that is not allowable, and I believe this tax ought not to be allowable.

speech.para: I refer now to the second part of the amendment. Senator Siddons spoke at length on tourism, which affects very closely my own State. The legislation would raise the very odd and very absurd items that tend to arise from such legislation simply because the Government initially did not even know who was able to be exempt and certainly it had very little idea of what was likely to happen to the various categories it was tossing out under the Diesel Fuel Taxes Legislation Amendment Bill. In relation to tourism on islands, for example, it is all right for a person with a launch to call it a ferry providing that he is engaged in ferry services. If the vessel happens to take part in cruises it is not exempt. If one were to put fuel into two identical boats, the one engaged in ferry activities would be exempt but the boat engaged in cruise activities would not be exempt. I seek from the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) what precisely is the difference between a ferry operation and a cruise operation.

speech.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —Minister for Social Security) (4.13)-It is clear that Senator Thomas has led a blameless life up to now and certainly has not been involved in the tax industry at all because his expression of horror about the wording of clause 5 suggests that he has not tried to read a lot of the sections of, for example, the Income Tax Assessment Act, which I think would make clause 5 look positively simple, straightforward and easy to understand. The fact is that some queries have been raised in respect of the definition of clause 5. Some of those queries have been answered but I do not think it would have escaped most honourable senators that however tax laws are drawn, even if the most beautiful simplicity is apparent, it is amazing what complications can be found. Undoubtedly, some time and effort will go into trying to push to the limit the extensions or the entitlements to rebates which are contained in this legislation. It would be very strange if that did not occur.

speech.para: As far as the amendment is concerned, I can share Senator Walsh's expression. It is with some regret that I oppose it. One would like to see exemptions widend . Nobody likes to see taxes imposed on any part of the community or on any part of the economy but it remains true-I accept his words-that there is to some extent an arbitrary decision to impose this tax because there is a requirement for revenue and it has to be raised from somewhere. In general, I would support the broad thesis that the tax should be as broadly applicable as possible and have as few exemptions as possible, notwithstanding that one might wish to see particular sectors exempted from it.

I have already addressed the question of whether local government benefits from the Budget or otherwise. I have tried to produce figures which show that it is not a pea and thimble trick, as it was described by Senator Walsh. Substantial moneys flow from the Commonwealth to local government through both a percentage of income tax and the roads program. On this occasion there is some impost on local government which, in a sense, simply makes local government compete on even terms with other sections of the community which would compete with local government in the provision of certain services and goods. For example, in the road making field local government is in competition with other elements and there is no particular reason why it should be treated differently from other people who provide that service. I have already addressed the particular exemptions in my response to the second reading debate. I do not believe that any other additional new points have been raised. I indicate that with some regret the Government also will be opposing this amendment.

Perhaps one other thing should be said. Senator Walsh indicated that the Opposition regards this Budget as the Budget of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), and he has to wear it. The Government wants the responsibility of wearing its own Budget. It does not want the responsibility of wearing a Budget which is being whittled away and changed to meet the political whims of the Australian Democrats. If we are to be judged on this Budget, it should be our Budget and not something which is pushed into some different shape by the Democrats' views.

talk.start.para: —In view of Senator Walsh's comments, I suggest that this amendment be put as a whole rather than as three separate paragraphs.

interject.speaker: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

talk.start.para: —There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

interject.para: That the request (Senator Siddons's) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Page 3, clause 5, proposed new section 164, sub-section (7), definition of ' agriculture', after paragraph (c), add:
'or (ca) the manufacture of food for live-stock,'.

This is not an amendment. It is a request moved by me in Committee for reference to the House of Representatives. It is simply requested to fix up an anomaly. I put it at that level in the hope that the Government will have a look at this request and see its way clear to resolving this anomaly. What my request proposes to do is to make the manufacture of food for livestock the basis for rebates under the definition of agriculture. At the present moment a substantial amount of food is being provided for livestock in situations of drought. I am advised by the industry in my State of Tasmania that, because of drought conditions, sheep pellets are being supplied at this time of the year, which is most unusual. Certainly those who will be affected by the failure of the Government to provide rebates in respect of food for livestock are the very persons in the drought affected areas for which the Government says it has a concern. I accept that the Government and the Opposition have concern for these particular areas but I suggest that they then support the Australian Democrats and me on this matter because, as I say, it really is an anomaly. In proposed new section 164 (7) (c) the definition of agriculture is stated as being:
The rearing of live-stock.

How can one rear livestock under drought conditions without manufactured food for livestock? We will have the situation in which a farmer gets in his tractor, puts sheep pellets on his trailer and goes out into the paddock. Under the provisions of this Bill, the tax on the fuel in the tractor is rebatable but the tax on the fuel used for the production of the livestock food carried in the trailer is not rebatable. If that is not an anomaly, I do not know what is. I understand that the Department has given a definition or an interpretation of the proposed new section which in effect excludes the manufacture of food for livestock. Frankly, I cannot understand that. It is not only the sheep grazing industry which is affected. Pellets for the pig industry and the poultry industry are also produced. I ask the Government whether in all fairness it could not go along with this proposition to request the House of Representatives to have another look at this matter.

I am aware that Government members in the House of Representatives from Tasmania would be quite anxious to look at this aspect if it were referred back to the House of Representatives. My advice from the manufacturer in Tasmania is that they have said that it is too late to do anything with the matter in the House of Representatives because the Bill is before the Senate. The object of this move is to give the House of Representatives and the Government a chance to have another look at what I believe is an anomaly.

speech.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —The Government has had some notice of this amendment as it was circulated and drawn to the Government's attention by Senator Harradine when the Bill was last before us. I have therefore had the opportunity of referring the matter to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) for his consideration. The Minister has confirmed that the Government would wish to oppose this legislation. I do not agree with Senator Harradine that this is a situation which is an anomaly.

speech.para: We have in the Bill a very broad definition of agriculture and it encompasses virtually all the activities which would take place on a farm, for example, pest control activities. That could be a very important element of a farmer's activities in these days, as in any days in farming. What the definition does not encompass is some exemption for the manufacturer of pest control goods which might be used on a farm. In other words, the exemption which is provided relates to activities which take place on the farm and not to activities which supplement the farm activities and which affect the goods which might be purchased for use on the farm. The Government, having established that exemption for the rural industries, does not propose to support any widening of the exemption to cover those industries which provide services which are ancillary to primary production.

I recognise the acknowledgment which Senator Harradine made when speaking to his amendment that both the Government and the Opposition have indicated their desire to provide support for the rural industries in this difficult period of drought. The best estimate that we have been able to make as to the value of the exemption put forward by Senator Harradine is about $1m. That is of necessity a guesstimate rather than a close estimate. The amount is not very large but the question is the extent to which one goes on redrawing the boundaries of the exemption. That figure of $1m stands in contrast to the drought relief legislation which passed through this Parliament last week and which provides for expenditure in excess of, I think, $360m on some of the additional facets of relief which are being granted in acknowledgment of the widespread and serious drought to which most of eastern Australia is subject.

I am pleased that we do not have to discuss this amendment in the context of an allegation that the Government is not concerned about the drought problems of farmers. Senator Harradine was gracious enough to make that point in his comments. I regret that I cannot in a similarly gracious manner acknowledge and accept his amendment, but the Government, having considered it, believes that would open up equally logical extensions which it does not think it should entertain.

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen P.A.

talk.start.para: —The Opposition will not be supporting this amendment-for all the reasons which I gave about 20 minutes ago and which I do not intend to repeat, and for one additional reason. In most cases what is excluded and included is substantially, if not entirely, an arbitrary decision. If we were to accept this amendment, given that Senator Harradine has introduced the present drought as at least a major reason for moving it, we would be supporting a change which would be both arbitrary and ephemeral. The Diesel Fuel Taxes Legislation Amendment Bill 1982 will last until it is repealed at some time in the future. The drought almost certainly will be finished next year.

speech.para: I make one other comment in case there is some misunderstanding. Whilst it is correct that pelletised food is fed quite commonly to poultry and occasionally to pigs, it is rarely fed to ruminants. In response to Senator Harradine's rhetorical question as to what, if the stock-we are talking about ruminants mostly-in drought affected areas is not fed with sheep pellets, will keep it alive, the answer by and large is that the food which will keep them alive is the components of the sheep pellets fed in their raw state.
Question resolved in the negative.

speech.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —Most of the other amendments that were circulated on behalf of the Australian Democrats are consequential upon the first amendment being passed. As it was not passed, it seems to me that it would be appropriate at this point not to press the other foreshadowed amendments circulated, with the possible exception of amendment No. 4 relating to the fishing industry. It states:

speech.para: except where that first-mentioned person sells or otherwise disposes of the diesel fuel to a person for use by that last-mentioned person in fishing operations.

The purpose of that proposed amendment was to make sure that co-operatives could seek the rebate on behalf of the fishing industry. I would like the assurance of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) on that point.

talk.start.para: —That is a matter I did touch upon in my response to the second reading debate but I obviously did not make the point clearly. The Government would be opposing that amendment but would in fact be picking up the position of co-operatives. I think the difference between the proposed amendment and what the Government is proposing is that we would not be widening the provisions to apply to fuel companies which might be providing the service but widening it to cover co- operatives. It is proposed to deal with this matter administratively. Those who are engaged in fishing operations who are working through co-operatives can be covered in a way which is satisfactory. Direct representations have been made on that aspect and that is one of the matters which will be dealt with not by amendment to the legislation but by amendment to the administrative arrangements .

speech.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —In view of the comments of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), the Australian Democrats will not proceed with the further amendments.

speech.para: Clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen P.A.

talk.start.para: —The Loan Bill (No. 2) is a Bill to finance partially the deficit by borrowing under the Government's defence powers for defence expenditure, which governments may do up to a limit of $1,500m. It is a measure that comes in every year, I believe; it has appeared in every year that I can remember. It is a completely normal machinery bill of government, although in 1975 it was said by some of the excitable people in the then Opposition that there were sinister motives behind it. Indeed, Senator Sir John Carrick became so excited that he described it as a corrupt device. It is certainly needed this year because the deficit estimated in the Budget of $1, 674m will clearly overrun by something between $650m and $900m on the expenditure side, and we believe that on the revenue side there will be a shortfall of about $1 billion.

speech.para: A significant reason for that revenue shortfall is that of the $225m which the Government had forecast that it would recover from its proposed tax recoupment legislation only a tiny fraction will now be recovered. At most we estimate it to be $37m, which will, from that item alone, cause a shortfall in revenue of $ 188m. Leaving aside the possibility that the estimate was rubbery in the first instance, that shortfall will be the consequence of two spectacular surrenders by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Government. The first of those surrenders was the decision to require vendor shareholders to pay 25 per cent of the tax liability assessed within 30 days of receiving the assessment and to give them 12 months to pay the other 75 per cent-in some circumstances, perhaps even more than 12 months.

It should be remembered that these people are the ones whom the Prime Minister described last month as recipients of stolen money. One may speculate legitimately and justifiably, I believe, as to whether the Government is about to declare that bank robbers and thieves in general will be given 12 months to repay the money that they have stolen once they have been caught. The 75 per cent tax liability assessed which may be deferred for 12 months carries, moreover, no interest penalty. Even Mr Sinclair pays interest on the money which he tells us his father stole from the Walsh companies. It is only at 10 per cent , admittedly, but at least he pays some interest. But these other recipients of stolen funds, as the Prime Minister has designated them, will get 12 months to repay the money that they have, and they will pay no interest.

The second spectacular surrender by the Prime Minister and the Government concerns the decision to exempt entirely an estimated 700 companies from the provisions of the tax recoupment Bill as it was first introduced. That is about one-sixth of the estimated number of companies, but in all probability a great deal more than one-sixth of the money is involved because they tend to be the larger companies. It is probable that something between one-third and one-half of the tax liability, as distinct from the number of companies involved, will now be forgiven. The criterion for that forgiveness will be where a company's untaxed profits were offset by losses against another company in the promoter's hands-apparently, in many cases if not in most cases, by Curran-type arrangements.

I find it quite extraordinary that a Prime Minister who was talking so rough and tough just a few weeks ago about his attitude to tax evaders, and even to tax avoiders if one cares to go back a little further, should have caved in so readily to these two propositions, the first of which defers into the next financial year at the very least the collection of 75 per cent of the tax evaded -the stolen money, as the Prime Minister designated it-and the second of which cancels permanently the Government's claim on something between one-third and one-half of the revenue which it has said it would collect. Again, I believe that one can justifiably speculate as to just who were the owners of those companies which are to be exempted by that spectacular surrender. One does not need to be very suspicious to suspect very strongly that the vender shareholders of those companies are very influential people in the Liberal Party of Australia . So, for a variety of reasons, this Loan Bill is particularly necessary.

The recoupment legislation, as originally introduced, was weak legislation never designed or claimed to recover more than a tiny fraction of the billions of dollars which had been evaded. It is now watered down as to be almost meaningless. It will, of course, to a very significant degree, blow out the Budget deficit which in part this Bill is designed to finance. It is, however, a normal machinery measure of government and will not be opposed by the Opposition . The consequences of the additional deficit blowout, caused by the Prime Minister's and Government weak cave-in to vested interests, the Government will be called to account for later.

Before closing I would like to add just one point with respect to the feeble excuse offered by Senator Sir John Carrick this afternoon and by the Treasurer ( Mr Howard) at the end of last week for this surrender to the people whom the Prime Minister has designated as recipients of stolen money. Senator Sir John Carrick's excuse was that unless people are given time to pay firms will be forced into bankruptcy and disemployment will result. He asked the rhetorical question as to whether the Labor Party wants disemployment. Of course the Labor Party does not want disemployment; that is why it wants to get rid of this Government. But Senator Sir John Carrick's excuse is phoney. There is a general provision already existing under section 206 of the Income Tax Assessment Act which allows the Commissioner of Taxation discretion in cases of hardship to defer the collection of tax which has been assessed. The technical legal view has been put to me that the recoupment legislation would not necessarily be covered by section 206 in the Income Tax Assessment Act. But there is, of course , nothing to stop the Government writing an identical clause into the recoupment legislation. So the Government has not only surrendered to people described by the Prime Minister as being most unworthy; it is now offering false excuses to try to camouflage the surrender.

speech.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —This Bill is being presented at a very early time in the current financial year. Last year the Loan Bill was presented much later and was for a much smaller amount of money. Last year's Bill involved only $300m; this Bill involves $1,500m. The Loan Bill for the last financial year was passed in the Senate on 19 May 1982. During debate on that Bill I said:

speech.para: By paying for defence expenditure with moneys from the Loan Bill other revenue can be diverted for non-defence purposes. Basically, the Bill is a short term measure to stop the Government going broke at a time when tax revenue is not coming in at a sufficiently fast rate. Since we are not in the business of bringing down governments we will not oppose this Bill.

We said last year and we say again this year that we are not in the business of bringing down governments so we will not be opposing this loan Bill. Of course, that does not mean, unlike apparently the Australian Labor Party's latest tactic , that we will not be seeking to amend any piece of legislation that has a dollar sign on it. We believe that the Senate has a legitimate role in reviewing all legislation and amending some Bills that may involve money. But this Bill, obviously, is fundamental to allowing the Government to govern and for that reason we do not intend to oppose it. However, we ask: Why is there the haste and why does the legislation involve this amount of money? We believe that this legislation could well be a symptom of the Government running short of money and having trouble meeting its immediate commitments.

I would like to remind the Senate of the economic policies followed by President Hoover in the early 1930s which directly contributed to the severity and the length of the Great Depression. Under Mr Hoover the money supply was drastically restricted at a time of economic recession, transforming that recession into a full blooded depression. Fearing inflation, the Federal Reserve or the central bank of the world's greatest economic power strongly restricted banks' reserves and starved the economic state of money. Taxes were increased, the economy was in a slump and the deficit was growing. The Hoover Administration and Congress agreed to raise taxes in 1931 by $900m or nearly 30 per cent. The Hoover Administration, however, had the spectacle of seeing revenue falling and the deficit increasing from a projected $1.2 billion to $2.7 billion. That is how the Great Depression eventuated.

There are other very obvious parallels between what happened in 1931 and what is happening in 1982. In 1931 interest rates in the United States suddenly fell dramatically-interest rates on call, for instance, fell from 20 per cent to one per cent between 1929 and 1931. This strongly restricted banks' reserves and starved the economic system of money. We are being stalked by the spectre of a depression. The demonstrations outside this chamber only a little while ago can only be a foretaste of what will come if this Government does not act quickly to establish a national consensus. I pray to God that we may fight off another depression such as I lived through as a small child. I fear, however, that the conservatives opposite are condemned by their ideology to inflict misery upon us . I hope that that does not happen. I hope that they see the need for consensus on an immediate and dramatic change of direction in the economic management of this country.

speech.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: —I thank the Senate for the speedy passage of this Loan Bill. As has been said by the Opposition, it is a machinery Bill. It has been brought in at this time to authorise borrowings for defence purposes. This can be done only prospectively. It is thought that at this stage, given the nature of the Budget and its deficit , this is the appropriate time and the appropriate amount for a Loan Bill for defence purposes. The Bill includes a specific limit to the amount of any borrowing that may be undertaken. The limit of $1,500m is the amount the Government considers reasonable to meet the prospective deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

debate.title: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

speech.speaker: Button Sen J.N.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: (1) That the following matter be referred to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence for inquiry and report as a matter of urgency: the effects on the aircraft industry of:
(a) the level of work needed by the industry in order to maintain skills in the industry;
(b) proposed retrenchments in the industry, as a result of the decision to cut by 30 the Nomad Project, on available skills in:
(i) technical management and design, and
(ii) trade skills related to aircraft production; and

(c) the cost of an extension of the Nomad Project to cover the loss of skills in projected retrenchments in the period between the rundown in Nomad production and the commencement of the F/A-18 and the trainer program.
(2) That no retrenchment of employees should take place until both Houses of the Parliament have debated the Joint Committee's report on this reference.

This motion relates to the Government aircraft industry in Australia. In a sense , the terms of reference are almost self-explanatory. In that industry a very serious situation has developed as a result of, in summary, a lack of availability or work, particularly at such locations as that of the Fishermans Bend Government Aircraft Factory. My major concern in moving the motion is that over the years Australia has assembled a skilled work force in the aircraft industry and the Opposition is concerned that that work force should be maintained as a cohesive employment group. If those skills are lost to the industry probably they will be lost permanently.

A number of reports on the Australian aircraft industry have been produced. One , the one hundred and ninety eighth report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on Government Aircraft Factories, concluded basically that the Government should develop comprehensive reviews of defence establishments, particularly aircraft industry establishments. As recorded at page 44 of the report the Committee recommended:
. . . that the Government consider, subject to normal commercial considerations, the greater utilisation by Departments and Statutory Authorities, the production capabilities of GAF.

Additional recommendations, including those on pages 42, 43 and 44, deal with a much wider concern-the need to retain continuity within the aircraft manufacturing industry in order to maintain existing establishments and the coherence of the peculiarly skilled work forces in those establishments. There is a sense of deja vu about my motion because it is almost a case of Bendigo Ordnance Factory revisited. I am not making partisan political points here. Maintaining the continuity of work in basically defence oriented industries and, consequently, maintaining the skilled work forces in those industries has always been a problem for governments.

There has been much criticism of the management of the Government Aircraft Factories. However, I have noted no criticism of the quality of the work produced or the talent and skill of the work force. This motion is moved in that context. Its effect is to ask the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence to report as a matter of urgency the effects on the aircraft industry of the level of work needed to maintain skills and the proposed retrenchments as a result of a decision to cut the Nomad project by 30 aircraft. It is also asked to inquire into questions of trade skills related to aircraft production, technical management and design and so on. There has been a good deal of correspondence about this matter between the Minister for Defence Support (Mr Viner) and personnel at the various aircraft factories. I understand that the Minister has now conceded that the original Nomad project, involving the production of 170 aircraft, the number first considered appropriate, should be carried out. I understand that that undertaking is given in correspondence with other members of parliament. That is the effect of what the Minister is saying. I am informed that even as late as today or yesterday some 38 employees of one of the establishments-I think Fishermans Bend-were retrenched. That process, unhappily, may continue. That is the point of the last paragraph of my notice of motion, which reads:
That no retrenchment of employees should take place until both Houses of the Parliament have debated the Joint Committee's report on this reference.

It is very important-I believe most honourable senators would agree-that Australia maintain an aircraft manufacturing capability for both defence and civil reasons. This parliament and governments of either political persuasion- again I am not making partisan political points-are faced with the necessity to look very hard at some of the problems associated with particularly highly- skilled based industries, such as the aircraft manufacturing industry, and the fundamental concern and need to maintain that capacity in Australia. For that reason the motion has been moved.

Senator Messner, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, has indicated to me that the Government would be anxious to include the word 'compulsory' in paragraph 2 of the motion after the word 'no' and before the word 'retrenchment'. No doubt the Minister can explain the difference, but I would not be averse to that amendment. In fact, I am appreciative of the Government's willingness to have this matter brought on. It is very important that it be dealt with as soon as possible. There is chronic anxiety in the industry about the possible dispersion of a skilled work force. That should be avoided at all costs.

In conclusion, I just mention that a number of members of Parliament, particularly the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), have been very diligent in negotiating with the Minister to try to see that something is done about this difficult situation. I feel that the Senate should take the course of approving the motion.

speech.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —I rise merely to say that the Australian Democrats support this reference to the Joint Committee of Foreigh Affairs and Defence. We believe that there is a very grave risk of the basic aircraft manufacturing capacity of this country being eroded to the point where it will disappear. The skills in the aircraft industry are very peculiar to that industry. Once they are dispersed they are gone and are very difficult to to re-establish. It is very difficult to re-assemble people with those sorts of skills. It is the old story-once an industry is dead it does not come back to life.

The Nomad project has been a highly contentious one. Nevertheless, some very basic research development work has been done on that aircraft. We understand a new tail plane has already been designed and is waiting to be tested. We would like to see that proceed, with the idea that that development could be incorporated in an additional batch of Nomad aircraft and could perhaps considerably improve the importance of that particular design. The Nomad, with all its shortcomings, does give us an aircraft which is capable of being used for surveillance purposes. As such, it seems that the Government could reasonably, logically and justifiably place additional orders for the Nomad until such time as other work can be phased in.
