I urge the Government to look at that matter very carefully to see whether we can get a suitable helicopter for manufacture here. The struggle of the Falklands proved beyond reasonable doubt -at least I would have thought it did-the need to have the capability to service and maintain aircraft and, in fact, to produce them within one's own country. With an island continent such as we live in, the defence of our shores requires a viable aircraft industry. We are isolated. We cannot rely on imports. We need to have self-sufficiency in this vital industry. The Australian Democrats are very pleased to support the reference moved by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button). The statement by the Government in respect of the stoppage of Nomad aircraft production was made, I think, on 7 May this year. The production limit set was 170 aircraft. Senator Siddons referred to the retention of the aircraft industry. He made specific reference to redesign work in respect of the tail plane of the Nomad and the possible benefits that that might bring for later marketing opportunities. The Government has given consideration to the capability of the aircraft for the kinds of purposes he has enumerated and the kinds of variations which he has suggested. The Government has come to the reluctant conclusion that 170 aircraft is about the maximum number that the organisation can market for the kinds of purposes that are deemed to be feasible . For that reason the Government obviously has accepted the advice of experts in this regard. It sees the need to stop production at that point.

If Senator Siddons has other suggestions in respect of marketing opportunities he may see fit to put those views forward at the forthcoming hearings of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. I guess that that is an appropriate thing for him to do. On present indications and given that there will be a substantial upgrading in the Government's marketing capacity in trying to raise the numbers of sales to the level anticipated-that is, 170 aircraft- then the objective of building 170 aircraft seems to be realistic. As was pointed out, there is a continuing program of reduction of employment in the Government Aircraft Factories. That was detailed at an earlier time and I will not go over it again. I will make the point that the greater part of this reduction in employment will occur as a result of natural wastage, through retirements and so on. Senator Siddons made a very substantial point, as did Senator Button, with regard to the retention of the aircraft industry. The Government certainly sees the need for this retention and in fact is encouraging it. As I believe was acknowledged at an earlier time, there is to be a substantial offset of work arising from the new FA18 aircraft program.

talk.start.para: —Not much.

—The value of the work to be undertaken by Australian industry under those arrangements will be 30 per cent of the imported content of the program and there are compensation provisions if the United States contractors should fail to meet those commitments. I think Senator Button would acknowledge that as a very substantial development. This would also include the export of Australian made components to United States contractors. I understand that considerable value is to be put on that. In fact, it means that some $60m would be spent on new capital facilities required in the aircraft industry. That would be a very substantial upgrading in Australia's aircraft technology. I think it should not be forgotten that this certainly does not represent the end of the road but rather an opportunity to move towards new technology with new aircraft. It means a substantial investment in a new aircraft that clearly will be of benefit to Australian industry in the future and clearly will have job creation potential.

speech.para: Naturally, the work to be done in Australia on the relatively small volume of Royal Australian Air Force F18 aircraft would cost more than it would have cost had the work been done in the high volume production lines in the United States. Clearly there will be an improvement in the satisfaction of those undertaking such jobs. Of course there will be future opportunities and interest in those potential jobs.

The Government has also recently authorised the design, development and production in Australia of a new basic trainer for the RAAF. Again, that demonstrates the Government's commitment to building a substantial capability in Australia. The acceptance of that cost penalty is a further illustration of that very point. The price we can sell it for is, of course, constrained by what the market will bear. There will also be a substantial upgrading of marketing capability in order to reach the production of 170.

To assist the consideration of the Bill at the Committee stage, I will apprise the Senate of recent developments and foreshadow the amendments that have been moved. The amendments have been circulated for the benefit of honourable senators. I take this opportunity to thank honourable senators for following up the suggestion made by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) when this Bill was last debated of circulating possible amendments that they might wish to move. The Public Service Acts Amendment Bill was first introduced in the Budget session last year. The Bill was the culmination of a number of projects undertaken to update the employment provisions in the Public Service. The major changes were to abolish the divisional structure of the Public Service, to revise the procedures for promotions and appeals and to revise arrangements for the recovery of outstanding debts from the salaries of public servants.

When the Bill was debated in the autumn session, the Government in the other place moved certain amendments to the Bill. They were: To provide a greater degree of autonomy to the Parliament in determining its staffing arrangements arising from the report of the Jessop Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing, to provide for the furnishing of reports giving reasons for decisions in relation to promotion matters and to provide for the dual appointment of permanent heads. The Bill, along with the Government amendments, was passed in the House of Representatives last session. During the winter recess, the Public Service Board has had extensive consultations with the unions representing the public servants. As a result of these consultations, and other developments to which I will refer shortly, the Government has decided to move further amendments to the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill.

Over the past few years, there has been a number of court judgments which have affected the promotion and appeal processes in the Australian Public Service. Prior to the introduction of the Bill in the Budget session last year, there was an important judgment on a promotions appeal case which indicated that the established procedures of the Promotions Appeal Committees were deficient. The judgment cast appeal proceedings into an adversarial framework requiring a far greater degree of legal formality than the Government considered desirable. For this reason, the Bill contained specific provisions which would have had the effect of allowing Promotions Appeal Committees to determine their procedures and therefore continue with the less formal arrangements that had existed before the judgment.

Since the introduction of the Bill, there has been a number of judgments which have stressed the importance of personnel management interests involved in the promotions appeal system. The effect of these judgments has been to offset largely the effect of the earlier judgment. The Government, in the light of these developments and of opposition from the unions has decided to amend the Bill to omit these provisions detailing the procedures to be followed by Promotions Appeal Committees. Amendments (5), (6) and (7) circulated in my name have this effect. The amendments moved by the Government will also delete from the Bill special provisions for the giving of reasons for decisions in relation to promotion decisions. These special provisions were inserted by amendments moved by the Government in the other place and passed in the autumn session. They would have had the effect of replacing the application of section 13 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act.

The Government was of the view that these provisions were necessary to protect the privacy of public servants involved in promotions and appeals. It was feared that the application of section 13 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act would have forced decision makers in the Public Service to reveal to an applicant confidential information about other parties to a promotion or appeal. This would have had detrimental effects on individuals as well as jeopardising harmonious working relationships in the Public Service. The effect of the recent judgments mentioned above, as well as developments in the legal processes for providing reasons for decisions, has been to minimise the problems of privacy in providing reasons for decisions. The Government has decided to accede to the requests of the unions and to delete those special provisions, contained in amendments (1), (11), (12), (16), (17), (18) and (21), which will have this effect.

Senator Button, in his speech on the second reading of the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill, foreshadowed an amendment to include a provision to give expression to the merit principle. The amendment proposed by Senator Button also made provision for inclusion in the Public Service Act of an anti-discrimination provision. Senator Button indicated that the amendment was supported by the report of the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration. The Royal Commission recommended that there be a declaration of commitment to merit in recruitment and promotion. The Government proposes a provision of declaration to the merit principle. It is the Government's view that the anti-discrimination part of the Opposition's amendment should not be included in the Bill. The very broad approach suggested does not adequately cope with the inherent complexities of personnel management in a large organisation. Such complexities require a proper legislative basis for exceptions to be made in specific instances. For example, current practice in relation to apprenticeship training involves discrimination on the grounds of age. The Government believes that the Opposition's amendment does not recognise current emphasis given to conciliation as the first approach to the redress of perceived malpractices. The Equal Employment Opportunity Board of the Public Service Board has successfully been handling such cases in the Public Service on the basis of conciliation and staff counselling.

Recently the Government announced the introduction of legislation to deal with sex discrimination and the existing Racial Discrimination Act covering racial discrimination aspects of the proposed amendments, while providing necessary exceptions and mechanisms for redress.

talk.start.para: —Stop all forms of sexual harassment?

—Perhaps there are some forms which Senator Chipp would prefer to see there. It is believed these developments, along with existing adminstrative arrangements, make the Opposition's anti-discrimination clause unnecessary. As a result of discussions between the Public Service Board and the unions, the Government is also proposing a number of amendments which I understand will remove the remaining points of possible contention. In the light of this it may suit the convenience of the Senate to debate the Bill as a whole with separate questions being put as necessary on the amendments.

talk.start.para: —I desire to say a few things in generality in respect of the amendments which are proposed to the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill. Since this Bill has been before the Senate there has been a certain amount of controversy about its provisions. I think that all honourable senators have received representations-as far as I am concerned they have been very useful and informative representations-on a number of matters which have arisen. Quite a bit of the controversy that did arise concerned the provisions of the Bill which had the effect, as it appeared at the time, of varying the determinations which Mr Justice Ellicott had made in the case Finch v. Goldstein . Since then further litigations have clarified the position of the law. I believe that has played a substantial part in affecting the Government regarding the removal of some provisions which were causing considerable controversy.

speech.para: The Bill contains a number of important matters. They have probably been lost to a certain extent due to the fact that people have objected to specific items. I mentioned by way of interjection that the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills had taken note of some matters which were involved in the Bill and had drawn to the attention of the Senate various items. So far as the present amendments are concerned, a number of them bring about clarification and satisfy the objections which the Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills raised. Amendment No. (4) leaves out clause 25, which was the subject of comment by the Committee in its eighth report. The Committee, in its eighth report, dealt with a number of other matters. Amendments Nos (6) and (7) delete the detailed provisions relating to Promotions Appeal Committee procedures that had been commented upon by the Committee. The proposed new provisions leave the procedures to be such as the Promotions Appeal Committee thinks fit. That is the expression which is used. Any procedure that the Promotions Appeal Committee adopts will still have to comply with the rules of natural justice.

There has been a number of decisions of the Federal Court of Australia since Finch v. Goldstein, the case which stimulated a number of the previous amendments. These decisions have stressed that the procedure to be followed by a Promotions Appeal Committee must be adapted to the particular case. It has also been clear that Finch's case was rather special and ought not to be regarded as stating the requirements necessary in each case. It is presumably for this reason, at least in part, that the Government has abandoned the attempt to codify the procedure. This does leave the Promotions Appeal Committee with maximum flexibility in its procedures, but it does not provide much guidance to the parties on an appeal. In view of the various decisions and somewhat differing attitudes of the judges, this may be all that is practicable at the present time. In that sense, I welcome these amendments.

Furthermore, amendment No. (11)-I will refer to each of them at this stage as we are dealing with them altogether-leaves out Division 5, which contains provisions on which the Scrutiny of Bills Committee had commented in its eighth report. These provisions were in respect of matters about which notice had to be given to the parties. Likewise, amendments Nos (19) and (20) omit clauses to which objections had been taken. The Committee also commented on clause 44 of the Bill. No alteration has been made in relation to those comments. I would consider, having given study to the various amendments which the Government has now put forward, that it does clarify a number of points which have been raised and which have caused difficulty. I strongly commend the Government on the way in which it has responded to the criticisms which have been made and improved this Bill.

speech.speaker: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

talk.start.para: —The Public Service Acts Amendment Bill has had a long and tortuous history. It was first introduced into the House of Representatives on 29 October 1981. I believe it has been an example of what co-operation between the various parties in this Parliament can do. It has been a triumph of good sense, of consensus and of accommodation of an opposing point of view and I strongly commend the Government for the way in which it has listened to argument and objections from both the Australian Labor Party in the House of Representatives and the Australian Democrats in this chamber.

speech.para: The Bill is designed to amend the Public Service Acts and other related Acts in mainly two areas, the first of which involves the abolition of the divisional structure of the Public Service. There is basic agreement on that objective; it is a most desirable and long overdue measure to streamline the Public Service. Secondly, it deals with the promotion and appeals procedure. There was a great deal of controversy in the House of Representatives on the proposed changes to the appeals and promotions procedure. The Labor Party moved a great number of amendments, which were opposed by the Government and lost. Before the Bill could proceed to the Senate, the case to which Senator Missen referred-Finch v. Goldstein-was decided. Mr Justice Ellicott decided that principles of natural justice should apply to appeals and promotion procedures; that is, that all relevant information should be made available to all parties concerned in these proceedings and in subsequent reports. The Democrats see this not only as natural justice but also as sound management practice and in keeping with recent and desirable trends in the Public Service towards open management and employee participation in public administration. I give as examples open performance appraisals, access to personnel files and counselling by supervisors, particularly prior to any disciplinary action.

The Government saw fit to introduce 14 pages of amendments designed to counteract the Finch v. Goldstein decision. It is only now, after months of belated consultation with the Public Service unions and after I had stated in September of this year that the Democrats would oppose the Government's amendments, that the Government has finally abandoned its efforts to counteract the 'natural justice' stance in the Finch case and drop the amendments

talk.start.para: —Senator, do you not give some credit to the fact that subsequent cases have varied the decision in the Finch case?

—Yes, I do. I have already acknowledged that. Before I leave this area I would like to express my personal appreciation and the appreciation of my party of the co-operation of the Leader of the Government (Senator Sir John Carrick) in providing us with access to the professional expertise of the Public Service Board during our assessment of this legislation. My staff and I also appreciate the hours of time that members of that Board have devoted to us in explaining the provisions of the Act and the Government's position. I now refer to the specific matter about which I want to talk. I am in the hands of my friend Senator Button; if he thinks I am going off before he should when I talk about specifics he should say so. Perhaps I should talk in general terms about the specific amendment I desire. Neither the Government nor the Labor Party, with great respect, has been prepared to tackle the area of discrimination in a manner which in my view is specific enough. It may be that in the event the way in which these amendments are interpreted will effectively kill discrimination.
—That is what we would argue.

—I know, and I respect that argument. If the Labor Party does argue that, I wonder why it stopped that one step short of being specific enough and putting it into the legislation. The amendment to the amendment to be moved by the Labor Party to section 33AA is the only amendment that we will move in regard to this matter. At the moment the Government's clause merely calls for ' procedures that involve careful assessment of personal qualifications and preclude unjustified discrimination'. The Opposition amendment does go further-I will not steal Senator Button's thunder by saying what it is-but we believe it does not go far enough. The Democrats are mindful of the need to ensure the effective performance of the work being undertaken.

speech.para: I must pay tribute to the Labor Party for the manner in which it co-operated in the almost joint discussions on this Bill held between the Democrats and the Government. It has been a very pleasing exercise in co-operation and consensus making. We fully support the need to exercise positive discrimination on behalf of the disadvantaged. In fact, I believe these efforts should be stepped up. Subject to these provisos, we believe it is time the Australian community made a clear, decisive and explicit stand against discrimination in all its insidious forms. I ask rhetorically my friends Senator Button and Senator Missen: Does the term 'discrimination on the grounds of sex' include discrimination against persons who are homosexuals and, if so--

talk.start.para: —Yes.
—I would think so.

—If it does, the Democrats simply ask why it is not specified in the Bill. This is one of the areas in relation to which we will move our amendment to the Labor Party amendment. If Senator Button does not mind-if he does, he should interject-I will conclude my remarks and let him continue with his speech on the specific issues. I want to put on the record some aspects of community attitudes towards homosexuality today. Thank God it is a subject that one can now at least raise in public forums such as the Parliament without being smeared, as I suggest would have happened just a few years ago. I refer to the Age poll of May 1978 which showed that a total of 58 per cent of Australians interviewed believed that homosexuals should be treated by the law in exactly the same was as heterosexuals. Another interesting finding was made by the American Psychiatric Association. In a statement released in 1973 it rejected that homosexuality per se implies any impairment in judgment, stability, reliability or general social or vocational capabilities. On 1 March 1978 the Board of Social Responsibility of the Uniting Church issued a statement supporting decriminalisation of homosexual behaviour in private between consenting adults.

speech.para: In New South Wales the Anti-discrimination Bill of 1976 at first outlawed discrimination against homosexuals. The Bill was delayed and was later passed with the offending clause watered down. It simply said that 'the Anti Discrimination Board may investigate instances of discrimination'. That is what worries me-the non-specific reference to discrimination against homosexuals in this Bill. The Royal Commission on Human Relationships, the Western Australian Royal Commission into Homosexuality in 1974, the New South Wales Anti- Discrimination Board, the Tasmanian Select Committee into Victimless Crime in 1978 and the Victorian Equal Opportunity Board have all recommended against the discrimination against gay people. Although not formally within its powers, the South Australian Equal Opportunity Commission in its annual reports of 1976-77 and 1977-78 noted that it had heard and mediated on numerous cases of gross discrimination on the grounds of homosexuality. They noted in the 1978 report that such complaints were not decreasing and mainly concerned employment. The reports of the Wilenski Review of New South Wales Government Administration, the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration and the Hope Royal Commission on Intelligence and Security all noted anti-gay discrimination and recommended against it. Perhaps reluctantly, somewhat hesitatingly and certainly belatedly, gay rights are now on the public policy agenda in Australia .

My two friends, Senators Button and Missen, both distinguished lawyers, if I may say so, interjected at my invitation saying that they believed that the term 'discrimination on grounds of sex' would include homosexuality. Both of them know, both being very distinguished liberals-if I do not offend Senator Button by that expression, and I probably do; I know I flatter Senator Missen-

talk.start.para: —Not at all. Senator Bjelke-Petersen described me as the nicest chap in the Senate.
—I think I should call Senator Button to order.

—I think you should call him to order if he makes remarks like that, Mr Chairman. I thoroughly support you. Both of these honourable senators know the insidious forms of discrimination that have been and are practised against homosexual people without the overt mention or the overt charge of homosexuality being brought to the surface. Somebody who is gay may have some other aspect of his or her behaviour, performance of conduct brought in as an excuse to discriminate against him or her. This is why the Australian Democrats wish that term to be included specifically in the Act. Mr Chairman, I am in your hands and I seek your guidance. Would it be appropriate for me not to move my amendment on the Australian Labor Party amendment yet but to exercise my patience until Senator Button has moved his amendment and then so move? Would that be the correct position?
—That is right. Senator Button has not yet moved his amendment.

speech.speaker: Button Sen J.N.

talk.start.para: —I have a great deal of respect for Senator Chipp's views. In a sense this is a constructive little debate in which I think concessions are being made on all sides in an appropriate way.
—Senator Button, are you still speaking on the Government's amendments? We have to dispose of them, I suggest, before we put your amendment.

—Yes, Mr Chairman. I will speak very briefly on the Government's amendments and then Senator Messner or Senator Missen may want to say something else. I do not know. I just want to reiterate the point, and this is of relevance, I think, to Senator Chipp's amendment to my amendment, that proposed section 33AA deals with the prohibition of patronage, favouritism, unjustified discrimination and so on. But the most important aspect of it, I suppose, is that it enshrines the principle of merit in Public Service recruitment, selection and transfer. That, as I pointed out earlier, is in line with the recommendations of the Coombs Royal Commission into Australian Government Administration. We would agree with the Government that it is the most important consideration in getting an efficient and effective Public Service, which we should all be concerned about.

speech.para: All I want to say about the Government amendments in a sense is that we fully support them. But the amendment which I will be moving and the one which has been foreshadowed by Senator Chipp must be seen in the context of proposed section 33AA which enshrines the principle of merit. Later on, when I come to deal with Senator Chipp's amendment, I will be pointing to what I believe to be some serious inconsistencies in Senator Chipp's amendment with relation to proposed section 33AA. I want to make that point at this stage in order that the Government amendments can be dealt with and then I will move my amendment a little later on.
Amendments agreed to.

speech.speaker: Button Sen J.N.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: Page 16, clause 21, sub-clause (1), proposed new section 33AA, at end of section, add the following sub-section:

'' '(2) Powers or discretions under this Act shall be exercised in a manner which does not discriminate in employment on grounds of race, creed, sex, age, marital status or political belief, except where reasonably and justifiably required for the effective performance of the work being undertaken, and except where such discrimination is part of a program of affirmative action for disadvantaged groups.'.''.

The wording of the amendment is important. We say it gives the authorities which appropriately have discretion in this matter a general authority in relation to dealing with questions of discrimination; that is, as it were, an injunction to them to avert their minds in dealing with promotion, recruitment, transfer and so on. We suggest that they have regard to the general principles of promotion by merit, but in applying that principle we ask them to avert their minds to questions of discrimination. We have referred to discrimination in employment on grounds of race, creed, sex, age, marriage status or political belief except where reasonably and justifiably required for the effective performance of the work being undertaken and except where such discrimination is part of a program of affirmative action for disadvantaged groups.

We think that is the best statement which we can appropriately arrive at in terms of the concept which we desire to see reflected in this Bill. That formula has been the subject of discussions between the Public Service organisations and the Government and has been of concern to the Public Service organisations for some time. I think it is best for me to move the amendment at this stage. I have some remarks which I want to make about Senator Chipp's amendment. I will not make them now; I will make them at a later stage. I have the greatest respect for what he is trying to do but I do not agree with the method by which it is being done. I want to say something about that when he formally moves his amendment.

speech.speaker: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: Proposed new sub-section (2), leave out the sub-section, insert the following sub-section:

''(2) Except where reasonably and justifiably required for the effective performance of the work being undertaken, and except where such discrimination is part of a programme of affirmative action for disadvantaged groups of persons , powers or discretions under this Act shall be exercised in a manner which does not discriminate in employment on grounds of race, creed, sex (including homosexuality between consenting adults), age, colour, language, national or social origin, marital status, birth or other status, mental or physical handicap, security record, educational qualifications or religious, political ethical or other beliefs.''.

The amendment moved by the Australian Democrats leaves out proposed new sub- section (2), that is, Senator Button's amendment, and inserts in its stead another amendment which is essentially identical to the amendment moved by Senator Button except that it adds specifically these grounds: Including homosexuality between consenting adults, colour, language, national or social origin, birth or other status, mental or physical handicap, security record, educational qualifications, religious, ethical or other beliefs. In moving that amendment I again state that the Democrats are not necessarily saying that if our amendment is not passed discrimination will be permitted under the terms of the amending Bill on the grounds that we are highlighting. I will be very interested to hear Senator Button give the reasons why he does not include matters such as homosexuality between consenting adults, colour, language, national or social origin or whatever. Why not specify them in the Bill? That is all this amendment serves to do. I would be interested to hear both the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) and Senator Button state why that is not acceptable to them.

speech.speaker: Button Sen J.N.

talk.start.para: —I do not want in any way to offend Senator Chipp. I think he has put up a valiant effort which has failed, and which has all the qualities of Custer's last stand. I do not know whether that is the appropriate expression to use in regard to what he has done. I think his idea is misconceived but with the best possible intentions, and I want to explain why. Proposed new section 33AA (2), which is my amendment which the Australian Democrats seek to amend, has to be seen in the context of proposed new section 33AA, the Government amendment, which as I said earlier enshrines the principle of promotion by merit. That is a view with which I hope the Democrats would agree. Promotion should be by merit. The purpose of moving my amendment, and in a sense the purpose of Senator Chipp's amendment, is to say yes-in the context of this legislation-promotion, transfer, et cetera, should be by merit but in assessing merit the employers will take a few other matters into account. In our amendment we have arrived at a formula which we think gives the employing authorities appropriate discretion. After all, it all depends on their discretion in the long term. We think our amendment gives them wide enough discretion to have regard to the principles which we seek to have enshrined in the legislation and the Democrats seek to take that further. Senator Chipp gave us the Gallup Poll figures on homosexuality or something-
—Not 'or something'-on homosexuality.

—Yes. Senator Chipp dealt with the issue of homosexuality. During his remarks he sought advice from Senator Missen and me about whether we thought the word 'sex' in my amendment included homosexuality. It is my view that it does because if an employer is looking at questions of discretion he will be asked to take those things into account. It does not just mean male and female sex. It could mean neuter-
—Lack of.
—Senator Missen said lack of. It could mean a variety of things in that context. We do not think that the word 'sex', except for the point of making Senator Chipp's points, is enlarged by the words:

speech.para: (including homosexuality between consenting adults).

I notice the word 'consenting' was added in handwriting on my copy of the amendment and I am grateful for that. We do not think those words add anything. As I said a minute ago, all this must be seen in the context of promotion by merit. Senator Chipp's motion then goes on to have regard to age, colour and language, which is fair enough. For example, it seems to me that one cannot take language into account in the way in which Senator Chipp wants to if there is to be promotion by merit because it is totally unacceptable, in my view, to promote to the Second Division of the Australian Public Service a person who speaks only Japanese. To take the words of Senator Chipp's amendment literally, that would have to be taken into account. There are a number of other examples of the sorts of things I mean. For example, the words 'mental or physical handicap' are used and the same comment can be made against them.

talk.start.para: —Have you not read the whole amendment?
—'Except where reasonably and justifiably required'.

—I understand that. We have all got that in. They are just buzz words, meaningless words in a sense. The honourable senator is saying that one takes all these things into account but they are ignored when one wants to. That does not seem to add anything. For example, educational qualifications cannot be taken into account in a system of promotion by merit in the way in which this amendment reads.
—Why not?

—The honourable senator would say that it was reasonably and justifiably required, et cetera. The Democrats have that qualification at the beginning. I really do not see that it adds very much to the sort of formula which is contained in the Opposition amendment because what that does, of course , is flag the important issue of discrimination. There is a Latin expression which is common to lawyers which I think is: Expressio unius est exclusio alterius, which means, roughly translated-if I get into difficulties I will rely on Senator Missen-that if particular categories or words are specified, that excludes everything else. That is the danger in trying to spell out in an amendment like this all the varieties of possible discrimination that one may be concerned about because one or two might be missed. If that is done they are quite clearly excluded from the Democrats' amendment, whereas they are not excluded from our amendment which is more general in its terms. I think there are very real dangers in spelling it out in such detail as the Democrats have attempted to do in their amendment to my amendment which, I say again, I believe to be drafted with the best possible motives and a great degree of concern which the Democrats have shown on this issue and which I think is commendable. That is why we do not support Senator Chipp's amendment.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

speech.speaker: Missen Sen A.J.

talk.start.para: —If I may enter into this small warfare I must say--
—You are going to speak English, aren't you?

—Most of the time I will speak English, yes. I will try to keep Latin expressions out of my speech as much as possible. I must say though, on that latter point that Senator Button mentioned, that he does not entirely convince me. There is a problem in specifying a number of things. In his amendment he specifies a number of things such as race, creed, sex, age, marital status or political belief and stops there. There is a danger that it may be said that other matters like physical and mental defects and so forth are excluded from the Opposition's amendment, so I do not think Senator Button escapes from the argument that he makes against the Democrats' amendment. Likewise that is a problem which he has. From that point of view one suggests that the Opposition's amendment should be expanded further. I doubt whether some of the proposals which are in the Democrats' amendment stand up very well. I think the point Senator Button made about language may well be justified. An effective performance of work may be done, but there may be reasons why someone who cannot speak English cannot be appointed to a particular job.

speech.para: Senator Button mentioned the security record. The person who is to be appointed might be splendidly efficient in the work to be undertaken but, if he has a security record which makes him an obvious spy for the Soviet Union, I think that must be taken into account. I therefore express the view that there are difficulties in the Democrats' amendment too as to whether some of those qualifications are satisfactorily described and should be taken into account.

On the other hand, as to the Government's amendment, I must say that the reference there is not only to it being by merit but also to precluding ' patronage, favouritism or unjustified discrimination'. I think that that is a very vague expression. With 'unjustified', it might be a very subjective judgment as to whether the discrimination is such. It might be a discrimination against Tasmanians, and it may be thoroughly justified that there should be discrimination against Tasmanians in appointments for the positions in question. I say that because there are, I think, no Tasmanians in the chamber at present; therefore, I can say that with safety.

In considering these amendments, my view is that the Government has not gone far enough. I think that an amendment along the lines of the Opposition's amendment is a better one-that there ought to be in the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill some spelling out of some of the provisions. But as I say, I am not sure that the Australian Labor Party has spelt out sufficiently the various grounds of discrimination which should not be taken into account, and I think that the Australian Democrats, in going much further than that, include some dubious grounds which should not, perhaps, be in the legislation. Whatever we do with the amendment or the shape of the Bill, the Bill will go back to the House of Representatives. I hope that it will be looked at again. I believe that there ought to be written into the legislation some more definite prohibition against discrimination and not just 'unjustified discrimination' because I do not know what that means and what we are intending to cover. The two amendments before us do not adequately cover the situation.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —Firstly, in dealing quickly with Senator Chipp's amendments, without canvassing the ground again I should like to make the same points as I believe Senator Button made; that is, as to the specificity of the particular points listed in the amendment, which limit rather than expand the capacity for exception and flexibility in the administration of this matter. That leads me to the point of the Government's opposition to the Opposition's amendment, which goes to fairly detailed lengths to specify areas in which discrimination is spelt out and which , I believe, will not adequately cope with the complexities of personnel management from day to day in the Public Service.

speech.para: It is necessary to consider a system of exceptions where there is obvious need for them. Such things, as I mentioned earlier, as the age limits applying to apprentices is one area. Another might be the fairly obvious example of the religious problems of people being appointed to countries in which their religion may not be acceptable-in the foreign service or the diplomatic service. The Opposition's amendment also does not take account of the existing structure for resolving discrimination malpractices using conciliation and counselling. Again, these are points that I made earlier. The Equal Opportunity Bureau of the Public Service Board deals with these kinds of cases with what is regarded as a substantial degree of success. Also, existing legislation, such as the Racial Discrimination Act and the proposed sex discrimination legislation which was announced only this month, will be capable of dealing with most of the common forms of discrimination and will provide necessary exceptions and mechanisms for redress.

The term 'programs of affirmative action' mentioned in the Democrats' amendment is a terribly vague term and it is difficult to comprehend how it might be interpreted in a day to day administrative format. I noted Senator Missen's remarks in regard to the point, but I draw his attention to the amendment in proposed section 33AA which spells it out in the final phrase and specifically precludes 'patronage, favouritism or unjustified discrimination'. Senator Button 's earlier comments in relation to the question of merit and whether proposed section 33AA refers specifically to that limb of the problem are not totally exclusive of the point that those statements draw our attention very clearly to the questions of discrimination on the kinds of grounds that Senator Button has envisaged in his amendment.

I note the concerns of Senator Missen. I believe that the generality of the point as outlined in the Government's amendment goes a long way to meeting his point. I hope also that Senator Missen will note the points that I made, albeit briefly, in regard to the need for some flexibility in the administration of these things, and hence the Government's decision to draw the amendment and proposed section 33AA in the fashion that it has. For those reasons the Government opposes both amendments-that is, Senator Chipp's amendment to the Opposition's amendment-and will support its own amendments.
Amendment (Senator Chipp's) to the amendment (Senator Button's) negatived.
Amendment (Senator Button's) negatived.

speech.speaker: Robertson Sen E.A.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: Page 7, clause 6, proposed new section 9B, sub-section (2), leave out all words after 'before', insert:
'(a) the Senate, in the case of a report concerning the Department of the Senate;
(b) the House of Representatives, in the case of a report concerning the Department of the House of Representatives; and
(c) each House of Parliament, in the case of a report concerning any of the other Parliamentary Departments.'.

I believe that the amendment is needed to overcome a drafting oversight. I believe that when the Bill was being drafted this list was missed out. It is clearly inappropriate to have the report of the Department of the Senate laid before the other place, and vice versa. The report of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing foreshadowed that the annual report of that Standing Committee, as it became-the Senate Standing Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing-be the report of the Department of the Senate. It would be quite inappropriate to have the President of the Senate in some way presenting it in the House of Representatives. So the amendment resolves the situation-the Senate reporting to Senate; the House of Representatives reporting to House of Representatives; and the Joint House Department reporting to both.

talk.start.para: —The Australian Democrats support this amendment. Will the Government please take this matter on board, because it seems to be something in the interests of the Senate at large?

—It is not clear to the Government that the amendment moved by Senator Robertson would achieve the purpose that he has in mind. The Government acknowledges the point that he makes but draws his attention to the fact that if he were to have it incorporated in the Bill, where he would like to see it, it would not have effect until after 30 June 1983. Therefore, the Government suggests that the best course to follow would be for it, as a government, to undertake a review of the point and to give an undertaking to bring in an amendment, if need be, during the autumn session of this Parliament, which will be before 30 June 1983, and consequently meet this point, which is applicable in the next financial year .

—With the greatest respect, there seems to be no reason at all why this matter should not be resolved at the moment. There seems no reason why it should be deferred. If we are clear that this ought to be done, we ought to proceed and do it now. I would not like the Minister to feel that I do not trust the Government and that I think it would not do this at a later stage. Some cynics may think this. However, let me just say to the Minister that we on this side feel very strongly that this amendment ought to be carried at this time. I believe that the numbers exist at present to see that it is carried. The appropriate thing to do to save time would be to accept the amendment.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —I merely made the point in the hope that I might expedite arrangements. But if that is the point, we will need to consider the amendment. If it does not meet the objective we will certainly have to consider a further amendment at a later time .

speech.para: Amendment agreed to.

question.speaker: Hearn Sen J.M.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 19 May 1982:

question.para: (1) Did the Department of Foreign Affairs send any representatives to the Worldwide Chemical Conference held at Fort McClellan, Alabama, in 1981; if so, what are the details, including the number of personnel, their substantive Public Service gradings, the dates on which those personnel were absent from Australia, and the cost of their participation.
(2) Has a similar conference been held or been planned for 1982; if so, what are the details of Australian involvement.

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) No. The Worldwide Chemical Conference was attended only by United States military and civilian personnel.
(2) Yes. A similar conference for United States military and civilian personnel was held on 28-29 January 1982. Again there was no Australian participation or other involvement in the conference.

question.speaker: Walsh Sen P.A.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

question.para: (1) Have the salaries and non-salary supplements paid to university vice- chancellors in Australia not been made public for a long period; if so, why.
(2) What are the salaries, and non-salary supplements, now paid to each of the vice-chancellors in Australia.
(3) What are the salary and non-salary supplements now paid to each of the chancellors in Australia.
(4) Are the salaries paid to university professors in Australia public knowledge.
(5) Are the salaries and non-salary supplements paid to the principles of colleges of advanced education public knowledge.

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Universities in the States are autonomous institutions established by the States under their own statutes. The determination and public notification of salary and allowances paid to their vice-chancellors is a matter for individual institutions to decide. However, from a funding viewpoint the Government has made clear that it will not provide funds for salary levels in excess of those set by the Academic Salaries Tribunal, and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act has been amended to empower the Minister to reduce grants where academic salaries, including those of vice-chancellors, are paid at levels above those recommended by the Academic Salaries Tribunal.

(2) The October 1981 report of the Academic Salaries Tribunal, which was accepted by the Government, set recommended salary levels for vice-chancellors as a basis for funding. For the Australian National University and universities of Sydney, New South Wales, Melbourne, Monash, Queensland, Adelaide, and Western Australia the level set was $59,572. For other universities the recommended level set by the Tribunal, as a basis for funding was $55,226. The Tribunal did not set non-salary supplements for vice-chancellors. The Tribunal has since its October 1981 report, reported on 10 August 1982 following a recent inquiry into academic salaries. This report recommended a salary level of $63,742 for vice- chancellors in universities in the higher salary group, and $59,092 for vice- chancellors in other universities. I announced on 8 October that the Government has agreed to the salary increases recommended by the Tribunal and will increase the level of 1982 grants for universities and colleges of advanced education.

(3) It is for individual universities to decide the allowances paid to chancellors. The Academic Salaries Tribunal does not set rates for chancellors whose role is an honorary one. I understand that no university pays a salary to its chancellor. Information on any allowances that might be paid to chancellors is not available.

(4) Salary rates for university professors are recommended by the Academic Salaries Tribunal as a basis for funding by the Commonwealth and are set out in the reports of the Academic Salaries Tribunal. In the case of the Australian National University, salary rates are determined by the Tribunal for professors. The rate set by the Tribunal in its October 1981 report was $43,904. In the case of the Australian National University three levels of $49,914, $46,651 and $43, 904 were determined. The recent report of 10 August 1982 recommended a salary rate of $46,977 for professors (ANU $53,408, $49,917 and $46,977). In addition to salary, certain differentials and loadings may be paid by universities to professors within limits set by the Academic Salaries Tribunal.

(5) The Academic Salaries Tribunal also recommends and determines salaries for principals in colleges of advanced education. The recommended levels are set out in the reports of the Tribunal. The October 1981 report recommended seven levels for principals as follows: $37,714, $39,969, $42,221, $44,478, $46,730, $49,360, $51,988. The report of 7 August 1982 recommended increases to the following levels: $40,354, $42,767, $45,176, $47,591, $50,001, $53,085, $55,627. In the case of Commonwealth institutions, the salary of principals is recommended by the Tribunal. The Tribunal does not set non-salary supplements for principals.

question.speaker: Walsh Sen P.A.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

question.para: (1) On what occasions during the past twenty years has Australia been affected by trade sanctions or bans applied by a trading partner.
(2) What was the nature and period of the sanction in each case.
(3) What was the reason for the sanction in each case.

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) to (3) The information available is that Australia has not been affected by trade sanctions or bans applied during the past twenty years in the generally understood meaning of trade restrictions imposed for political reasons.
